content:
Posted: March 4, 2015
What is rage, you may ask?  Let me answer that question of yours.The game is set in a post-apocalyptic future, where the civilization as we know it, has been destroyed by the asteroid 99942 Apophis in 2029. Survivors have created settlements and other habitable locations and have been divided into various clans and organizations of their own. Bandits and mutants constantly roam the world and try to salvage and destroy the settlements.The story is your basic, “save the world story”. I could not get into the story of this game, it did not draw me in with anything special. I found no connections to the players actions except saving the world, but you are not greeted with an explanation to why the protagonist do the things he does. The protagonist is a mystery, who just happens to emerge and wants to save the world. I guess that you do not need more information to why you save the world, but it is a detail I would like to see, as to why the protagonist to the choices he does.The protagonist, is an “Ark Survivor”. You emerge to the surface as the sole survivor from your Ark in 2135, and you are immediately thrown into the harsh world that is left. You are greeted by some bandits trying to salvage the wreckage of your ark, you are in an bad position as you lack weapons and equipment, but fear not because you are saved by a wasteland settler, who will teach you how the new world works. From here on it follows a linear story, where you do quest after quest which takes you further up in the world, and soon people will start to hear rumors of the “Ark Survivor”, and form here on the journey only gets harder as you try to save the world from its misery.It is not that I disliked the story itself, I just could not find myself caught in it. I just followed the quest, did what I was told, and not long into the game I started to forget the story itself. But fear not, the story may have been weak for me but there were many other things that weighted in for it.The gameplay itself is what lured me into this game, this is what kept me coming back to the game. It is very action based, with a lot of gun-play, and a few stealth mechanisms if you manage to pull them off.This action is where all the fun resides. You can find yourself stuck waist-down in a firefight, with grenades flying from both sides, until you emerge victorious or die trying. But you do not actually die, since the Ark suit that you wear through the game has a built in defibrillator, so when you are about to die you enter a second chance mode, where you can revive yourself with a percentage of health and take out the enemies around you.I found that the AI was very good, and they have some of the more interesting mechanics, comparing with other games. Bandits dodge your shoots by doing acrobats, tactically advance and fall back depending on their amount, their health and how much health I seem to have. Mutants however swarm the area around you and charge head in, towards you, and jumps around to confuse you.There are not so many different enemies. There are three main categories, Bandits, Mutants and Authority. Each of the three has a number of different subcategories, where you find a handful of changes like, different weapons and different armor, changes in movement and size. Sure there are only three main enemies, but with the subcategories and all the changes in between the enemies, you get a very dynamic feel towards what you are fighting. There are some bosses in the game, which are a nice asset. One is the huge of a ten story apartment and takes some time taking down until you learn the tricks, and another might just be a bandit in some bulky armor shooting rockets at you. I found the bosses to be a nice change from the regular creeps that are sent at you, and they offered a nice amount of challenge, to keep it hard and interesting.The enemies had some changes with weapons, but what do you get?  You get an arsenal of ten weapons if I am correct. At first I thought that this was not enough, that it became to repetitive running about with the weapons you had, but all of that changes soon enough, when I was introduced to different kinds of ammo and equipment. Some weapons got explosive ammo, some got electric, some even got mind-control ammo. There was so many joyful ways to take down your enemies that I had a hard time choosing which was my favorite. The game rewarded you with different types of equipment, your primary were regular grenades, but you also had EMP-grenades, wingsticks (A triple-bladed boomerang), RC cars and some other things that I did not pay so much attention to.There was a nice amount of side quests that you could do, from eliminate, protect, save, gather, races and delivery missions. They offered a nice variation to the linear and dull story, but there was one thing that blew away all of the side missions and that was BashTV, and arena where you could fight through some of the weirdest, immerse, amusing and engaging rooms filled with mutants of all sorts. I spent a lot of time in this arena, rampaging about with my weapons as I had to dodge enemies, spinning blades from the roof, spikes from the floor, you name it.A game cannot be perfect, while there was a lot of things that stimulated, but there were also some things were dull and for me destroyed the feeling of immersion. The first thing I have already mentioned, and that is the story. Then we have the world. From time to time the world appealed me, with how everything seemed to have adopted to the apocalyptic world, how the some areas felt unique. I found it to be way to empty from time to time, and I saw repeating patterns in how the enemy areas were made. There were no weather changes, which withdrew some of my immersion. I also felt like the textures on the environment were to low res from time to time, and badly made, compared to the weapons, characters and vehicles. I had some trouble with the rendering from time to time as well, seemed like the textures were not loading as they should. Other than the problem I had with the look of the textures and their rendering from time to time, the game looked good. It fitted the scene of an apocalyptic world as it was supposed to, sure there was the feeling of it being to empty at certain points, but what else is there to be expected from a game like this.The controls were completely fine, everything did as I wanted it to, when I wanted it. The only thing I disliked about controls was that the camera was locked when you were in a vehicle, I would have liked it to be move able so you could watch around more. but I managed to look past it and enjoy the game for what it was.The voices were well made, sometimes you got the feeling that some of the voices did not fit in at all, but it was quickly overlooked. The game had a nice soundtrack that kept the immersion in place, and made you feel like you were in the heat of the moment. Then we have the weapon sounds, I loved the sound of the weapons in this for some reason. To me they were very realistic, and the sound of someone blowing up or being electrocuted was amusing in so many ways, that it was close to disturbing.Conclusion:The game Rage, is a very fun game to play, if you are able to overlook the issues that I found. I enjoyed it once I overlooked the issues, and I played through the story in about 8-9 hours. For me this time was well spent, by blowing stuff to pieces, blasting them in the face with a shotgun or trying the stealthy approach with a crossbow. If you are a person that likes the action based games where it is a lot of shooting involved, and do not mind if the story is the weak part, f

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 21, 2015
												I feel this is a title that gets less attention than it deserves, so I figured Id farm up a steam task and do a lesser known game some due justice in the process...RAGE is a game developed by one of my favorite developers of all time: ID Software. Because of this, I have massive fanboy goggles on, and am aware of this fact, and now you are too. Keep this in mind, and so will I whilst writing this.My first impression when playing this game was extremely positive. The opening cinematic, while being incredibly simplistic, does wonders for this game's atmosphere and is just downright beautiful. You are placed into the game without being assaulted with exposition, and I like that, so long as I can get it at my own pace during play. Discovery is one my favorite aspects to any game. The Visuals in this game are fantastic, ID has always been ahead of the curve in the graphical department, and this game really had me drolling with its visi-porn. This game gave me a gamer erection right away, and it persisted for much longer than 4 hours. The meat of the gameplay consists of roaming what remains of civilization while both on foot and in a vehicle with the goal of surviving, learning about your own history, helping remaining survivors that want to help you, and obliterating everything that wants to eat you. Driving, shooting, and shooting while driving are what you do in this game: and those things are FUN. The gunplay is quite good because the weapons are fun, visceral, and ammo is customizable. Each meaningfully unique weapon has meaningfully unique ammo types, making it one of my favorite things about the entire game. Enemy AI being strong also helps make combat satisfying. Driving is fun because cars are customizable, badass looking, responsive, and responsible for lots of great vehicular manslaughter moments. I thought I would dislike the driving, as its main purpose is for what you'd thinks its for: going places. Thankfully, going places is actually fun, and it never takes a painful amount of time, even when you have kill people who get in your way when all you want to do is get to the mission location.Exploration in this game is done in a way unlike any Ive seen. The game is a linear game but manages to not feel like it, and rewards mucking around and looking behind buildings and rocks that you would never need go near in the first place. Random junk like wires and cans all have resale value, and some can even be used to make random gadgets and gizmos on the fly, most of which are there just so you can mess around with more ways to murderize your enemies. The 'Engineering' in this game doesnt feel like a way waste your time or gate your progress, it feels like something a wastes wanderer would actually do given his circumstances and is way more fun than something so mundane should even be. Making RC cars with bombs stuck on them to blow up enemies who arent aware of you is fun, and is just one of 1000 ways to kill your enemies. Enemy and location design is also very good. Some missions are much scarier than I thought they would be just because of the locale and enemies within. While everything has that "crumbly, abused, neglected, dirty, or repurposed" design that most post-apocolyptic games have, it still remains memorable to me even though its been awhile since ive played. Variation in the urban and natural areas keeps it not feeling all samey, at least most of the time. The story remains vague initially, which like I said before, is something I actually like. As you begin to discover and learn more and more, the game becomes truly engrossing, and had me invested fully, since it all felt as though I had discovered it, rather than it being rammed up my bum because I needed it to understand whats going on. Unfortunatley right during the biggest highs this game's story creates, the game ends unforgivably abrubtly. The sudden and supremely limp ending to the narrative and game as a whole is THE WORST IVE SEEN IN ANY GAME EVER. YES, EVEN WORSE THAN MASS EFFECT 3. Overall: The game succeeds at being a wasteland explorating, baddie smoking, vehicle smashing, scavenging and wrecking fun fest. I had a really great time with this one, and I recommend it to anybody who has liked any game where you pick up a gun and rearrange a guy's face with it. This game is very underrated and underplayed.GOOD:-GUN DESIGN-AMMO TYPES-VEHICULAR COMBAT/RACING-VISUAL QUALITY-ENGINEERING/SCAVENGING-ENEMY AI-F%$#ING STUFF UPACCEPTABLE:-ENEMY DESIGN-LEVEL DESIGN-NPCS-LORE-LEVEL NAVIGATIONBAD:-THE ENDING IS ATROCIOUS-A FEW SERIOUS BUGS

content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												I HONESTLY BELIEVE THIS GAME SHOULD ONLY BE BOUGHT ON SALE!!!Alright, now that I've gotten that out of the way. .  If you're a fan of Fallout 3 and post apocalyptic settings, first person shooters with a variety of guns, like driving vehicles around and even racing them in a side game, then you'll enjoy this game. It's a linear fps with an okay story, some very repetitive quests, lots of driving around like in Borderlands, and it's not all that intricate. You don't assemble any weapons, but you can buy an upgrade every here or there. The voice acting isn't the worst in the world. You don't get to set what your character looks like at atll. The game starts you right in the middle of nowhere, but you're immediately given a mission and a gun. From there on out, you do his missions to gain a couple more weapons and your own race buggy, though you don't really have to race all the time. I hated the racing aspect of this game, but since I went into it with gloomy expectations, I wasn't let down much at all. It was pretty simple, laid back and had a lot of tacked on side games and side quests. I hear the multiplayer is d-e-a-d dead! So it'd be for the single player experience if you're thinking of getting it right now. Which I've heard lasts around 8-10 hours to beat, depending on how much exploring or time you sink inot the side games. All in all, for what I paid, I got a good amount of play time just waiting for me to log back in, but I wouldn't have purchased it if it hadn't been on sale. I'd say if you like SP FPS and a good sale, get it. If you like shooters that have a multiplayer slaughterfest of 1 on 1 or team vs. team, then this is definitely not the game fore you. But I think if you can get it and the DLC for 7 or so bucks, you should.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 30
												I thought that it was overall not a bad game, but it lacked depth. This game competes with Fallout 3 in terms of setting and mood. The graphics are nice. The shading and lighting is a lot better than Fallout. It feels a bit low poly and some of the textures are washed out despite the otherwise impressive engine.It is very smooth, even at highest settings.The gameplay is nice, but not ground breaking. I severely disliked the feeling that you are on rails the entire time. You can not even jump over small obstacles. There is always only one way to get to where you need to be. Everything is very scripted. Enemies will appear out of nowhere because of the way things are scriped. Your path will frequently close behind you, blocking your way back. As a result there is no finesse to the combat. You can not sneak up on the enemy and take them out silently (forget about the boomerangs, they are worthless). This is something that games like dishonored did a lot better.The engine would have provided the technology for an open world game like Fallout but they did not use it. It is a bit of a shame.There is no way to advance your character and learn new things (it is just a shooter, alright). You can buy a few items to boost but that is about it. There is the whole driving and racing element to the game. While it is fun, it feels like a separate game all together and very disconnected from the shooter part. The story is very linear and is lacking depth. It is also quite short. Where do those mutants come from? Why did they mutate like that within 100 years? We never get to meet people behind the authority. Why are they doing all of this anyway? We meet a lot of characters but we never get to really know them.Finally something for the game designers (and not just in this game but many post apocalyptic games): Why does no one clean up?! People occupy some ruins and install all sorts of traps and machinery but no one bothers to clean up and make the place livable? And why is there is still power in all those abandoned ruins? It makes so sense!

content:

												I would reccomend rage on a sale or free. (That is how I got it).  It was very visually appealing, lots of rich terrain and infastructure. I felt like as soon and I got a feel for the game it was over. There are two main areas with what seemed like a dozen or so quests per area and then it is over. (I logged about 30 hrs, but really 20 of that was pushing the quests).The weapons were pretty fun (like watching enemies dance when you hit them with a dynamite dart in the hand) but again I wanted more interaction with the Authority. I wanted more technology from them coming at me and more difficult bosses.  The weapon ranges were pretty cool and I wish there were some challenges in the game that demanded creativity in the choice of weaponry and bots.  You could basically go through the game and use only the shotgun pop rockets and the fat mamma's and be fine.(another fun one is the flame thrower guys.. just shoot them with anything you have and they will sort-of turn away... when they turn away exposing their fuel tank shoot the valve and BOOM)From 0 to 100 I would rate it in the low 70's.  I won't likely play it again.  Pretty fun though.Seems like a book, or series of books about this subject would be better. I really wanted more detail about the post-apocolypse and how the authority came to power and what sort of technology they had. Didn't get much of that.

content:
Posted: July 21, 2014
												This is DOOM creator´s Jhon Carmac last piece of♥♥♥♥♥♥Bethesda should know better than join up with ID software. The Game falls short right in the second wordlmap - this is ID´s post apocalypse shoot gallery with vehicle races, but if you tought "ELDER´S SCROLLS!" when you saw BETHESDA in the credits, look more carefully and you´ll see ID´s software is there too. The graphics are amazing and the game is open-world... if you consider a two-square mile canion with uninteractive gorgeous scenarious where you CAN´T GO open-world. You race in normal races and stupid ones where the objective moves constantly - so even if you tuned up your car you end up losing because you have no idea where to go - and battle with them, either against easy enemies or an horde of final ones, inside and outside the lanes. This was supposed to be a post-apocaliptic race battler with RPG elements. What´s the problem with it? ID´s software dumb touch is the problem. Closing the player in a dead end with either a wave of enemies or big bosses, dumbly blocking strategical positions and exits with impassible little fences, like DOOM does. limiting ammo and grinding, removing maps from interiors so you get lost after you finish the level (the old 'where the ♥♥♥♥ next?!?'), and the most imcompetent corpse-looting in the history of games (not like STALKER where you can loot weapons, or Elders Scrolls where you can even loot armor: this♥♥♥♥♥♥get 5 Bucks per corpse and a little random ammo). Yes, it´s just like a Bethesda game... if you diminished scenario, casualized inventory and cutted the open world to a little canyon. I rarely write reviews, but after THIS game all i can feel is... RAGE.

content:
Posted: November 22, 2014
												Careful before buying: the game doesn't use steam cloud it only saves locally so back up your saves with Gamesavemanager.This is unimpressive compared to masterpieces from id like Doom and Quake 1-3 mainly because those games redefined and changed everything, but it still has it's merits. To id's credit it is a creative game that has solid, smooth combat and great weapons and enemies, one of the smoothest running engines I've ever played, and also great sound effects. It has great graphics (besides the god awful mushed textures up close) and very nice presentation value and is a lot of fun to play. The combat is really very good, top notch. One big thing that makes combat so awesome is that all weapons sound very good. The weapons sound loud and hard hitting, especially when I blow a guy into outerspace with a point blank shotgun blast and it kabooms in my ears through my headphones.id software worked with Bethesda so Bethesda had some say in it and probably nudged them towards making it a wasteland game like Fallout 3 since it was so wildly popular at the time. That's OK, but I miss the evil satanic neo-gothic stuff from Doom and Quake. It also has a horrible last boss and ending. You do many things and craft and quest and so on, then the game just ends. But id knew they ♥♥♥♥ed that up and there's an expansion that lets you play even after the final boss.This game was an experiment for id to showcase their new engine which is incredible, as I said one of the smoothest game engines I've ever seen. It performs flawlessly. Although the graphics are beyond horrible in some areas, like ground and stationary surface textures. Just a blurry mess. Actually you know what, the graphics in this game just suck balls, period. Fantastic art direction, suck balls graphics quality. Oh and if there is one thing that id absolutely cannot do, it is racing. The racing parts in this game just ♥♥♥♥ing suck and are horribly sleep inducing. Also, the mouse pointer in game menu's, all of them, never feels right. It just doesn't move normally, but loose and crappy.Despite the games numerous merits, it doesn't live up to id's standards when you compare it to Doom and Quake 1-3. It was like they said "we are going to create a good game even if it kills us" and to their credit, they did that, but therein lies the argument that prevented this from being their next mega-hit. But RAGE holds it's own for what its worth: a wasteland FPS with very solid mechanics, a phenominal game engine besides the suck balls graphics, and not much else to complain about other than id's standardized approach to it's production quality.Lets just hope that John Carmack didn't leave id software because this game and future projects are what their production mentality is starting to curve towards. Let's hope that we actually see them bring back the magic when they put out Doom 4.Edit: DOOM 4 is the BEST GAME EVER7.5/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 4, 2013
												If you can get this game on a budget, then its a great buy....granted most purchases are... ha ha ha. This is a good game.  Its not quite as action heavy or remarkable as say ...."Doom" made by ID, but it still has good things about it.    If you've ever played Fallout 3 you may have been impressed with the vastness of that game regarding the places to travel, guns to use, things to shoot, and people to meet.   Rage takes a diffrent approach by offering "quality" over "quantity"  Not saying that Fallout didnt have quality, but Rage gives a smaller, more polished and prettier experince.   You dont have as many places to go, but damn it looks georgous and you even get some sweet rides to take you there (the optional races in those rides are fun too).  You may not level up your character, but you get some wicked high-tech gadgets to become force multiplyers.   There may not be as many guns, but the guns you do get all have a role that never gets tossed aside and you obtain deadly new varities of ammunition  that changes how they operate and the level of carnage they can cause. The graphics are amazing.  The character details are amazing.  The animations and behavior of the things trying to kill you are amazing.  No joke, its great to have one of the Ghosts do a parkor flip off the side of a wall to avoid your shotgun blast.  I was even suprised to notice that a NPC computer controlled ally of mine maintained realistic gun control and even kept their trigger finger outside of the trigger guard until he was ready to shoot.  Its this great level of detail that makes Rage a new experince that I would encourage others to try.  Whats not so amazing?  The way it ends.   It seems like such a great build up for something that doesnt ever seem finished.  Perhaps they put too much detail in other things and they just ran out of time and/or money, but it seems like it ends to abruptly for a proper ending.  Not really timewise, but gameplay wise.Also after completing the main story and the DLC you're going to be quite constrained.  In fallout and borderlands you can at least go around the land and shoot things.... in RAGE ( please correct me if I'm wrong) you cant unless they changed something in an update that I dont know about.  Once you beat an area enough times that area is closed off.  Kinda lame.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 10, 2014
												Rage is a classic first person shooter with a post-apocalyptic scenario.Graphics:     7/10The good news is that the game on the whole looks very good. When you play it for the first time you will have the "wow-effect" as soon as your character leaves the survivor capsule. The particle effects are not exeggerated and suitable. When you get the first weapons you will agree that the developers put some work into them. They may not be everbody's taste but the visual quality is unquestionably good. You can say the same thing regarding the environment.The bad news is that if you look a bit closer at the textures you will be very disappointed. Some are very blurred and directly next to them some are razor-sharp ones, what underlines the blurring even more. It looks like someone mixed Crysis 3 textures with Minecraft textures. Nevertheless the game has a good appearance concerning the graphics.Sounds:     6/10The weapon sounds are really powerful (especially the shotgun). Usually the rule is "the louder the gun the more damage you do". The cars have a nice engine noise. While most of the enemies say nothing or have nasty sounds you don't want to hear the villagers have pleasant voices. I appreciate that the developers tried to give everything a sound. That made the game lively and authentic. Due to the really bad enemy sounds I give 6/10. The developers could have made it better than that.Gameplay/Handling/Equipment:     9/10It's an ego-shooter, you will get what you expect. You will spend most of the time shooting mutants and bandits. To keep the player entertained the developers wisely added some side missions to break the monotony. Besides that you can gamble, enter an extensive racing competition to win car upgrades and new cars, play cards with a "trading card game" or risk some fingers in the knifegame. The handling is nearly perfect. You can quickly change weapons and ammo type, draw your grenade or fix yourself up. Steering a car is really easy. The equipment is very nice. The different ammo types make the game interesting. If you are tired of normal shotgun ammo then craft explosive ones to transform your shotgun into a grenade launcher. Especially the crossbow has a lot of special bolts.Level design:     8/10The level design is pretty narrow with some exceptions. This makes the combat straightforward and the shotgun your best friend in close quarter combat. The exceptions are mostly the parts where you are driving the car. Sadly there are only two or three sniper side missions. The level routes are very interesting and sophisticated. You will have few monotonous areas in the game. The only really monotonous part is the open world which connects the mission locations.I loved the level where I had to go to the destroyed city to get the defibrilator-upgrade. It gave me a real apocalyptic feeling.Enemies/AI:     5/10The AI is relatively poor. Except for some scripted events the enemies are just charging at you or are not using the covers properly. They don't have teamwork or act structured. Well at least some enemies use special abilities like the "octopus-like" enemy with the hook. The enemy variety is relatively low but it doesn't really matter.Story:     3/10The beginning and the basic idea was actually cool but it seems that the developers lost their creativity in the end. You are a survivor of a meteor impact and then... well and then you have to deal with the new world. There are some people who want to use the rescue-capsule for something and you want to free the civillians from the enemy influence and make sure that the capsules don't fall into enemies' hands. I don't really get it, what's so damn important about the capsules? They missed the "legendary" reason to fight a big bad company. Im sad that they wasted potential here. Even I could have made a better script for a story. And the biggest disappointment awaits at the very end. No big fight (not bigger than before), noone really cares and nothing you could call an ENDBOSS. The game was made to have an endboss. I was 100% sure of it: There has to be one. But poof. Nothing at all. Borderlands 1 had a crappy Endboss but at least they developed one.Critic summary:     6,3/10Personal fun rating:     8/10     [very good game]With all it's problems and missed opportunities the game is still worth a try.If the developers make a sequel I desperately hope for them to implement an endboss.The game may not have an exciting ending (extremely boring to be honest) but the gameplay and the atmosphere at the beginning and midgame is really enjoyable.I recommend it to buy it for 10 bucks or less.

content:
Posted: January 1
												 If youre going to buy this game, you will probably need to do a lot of googling to fix everything, however i can give you a head start paste this into launch options if youre having trouble with texture pop, low fps, and freezing +fc_maxcachememoryMB 2048 +cvaradd g_fov 12 +com_skipIntroVideo 1 +image_anisotropy 16 +image_use +jobs_numThreads 1, theres a bit more to it but that were some of the harder to find stuff, and see how to create a cache folder, and a config file, Google them theyre not hard to find (youve gotta paste some stuff into the config file). Also this game is really good, if youve got the patience to make it work.

												In this game you play as Trigun.  You and your astronaut buddies get to sleep in the space shuttle, but it's actually just a set on the hoover dam.  You wake up 40,000 years later to find that the world fell apart because the UAC decided to use the Moxim bolts, instead of the higher quality Mixom.  You drive around in a mad max esque waste land, throwing propellers at guys, even though there are no boats.  The end boss of the game is John Carmaks head sewn onto a 3d high res model of Commander Keen, who throws flaming garbage cans at you.

content:
Posted: August 3, 2016
												It was a decent game. To start things off we'll talk about the setting. Rage is set in a post apocalyptic wasteland, the scenery is mostly vallies of stone and sand with remnants off dead trees and various other small flora like dune grasses here and there. Not a whole lot,though it is a desert like setting where water is scarce so it makes sense. The general vibe is very steam punkish with a lot of rust and metals with weapons ranging from modified crossbows to machines to plasma cannons etc.. Indoor settings are mostly tech like and/or mutatant infested sewers or a combination of the two.The graphics were well enough. I played through on medium settings and it looked good and ran rather smooth on my laptop. No blocky square head or hands, the animations weren't clunky and looked proper enough for the actions. The controls were easy enough to get accustomed too ( you can change them anyhow if you don't like them in the settings) and were accurate. They were a bit sensitive though.... During gun fights they were well enough but the cursor on menus was insanly sensitive. Straffing was very fast as well, peaking around corners for stealth turned into full blown assaults very quickly lol. The jump button was pretty pointless as well, I couldn't jump over anything at all in the game and I tried just about everything >.< .Sound was alright along with voice acting. Never had to shove my head into my screen to here characters speak or had stuttered speech. Few well known actors voiced.Haven't played alot of multiplayer yet but from what it seems it is  Racing, V.S, and Team version campaign missions from the game. All in all I loved the game and reccomend it to others. My biggest dislike was the fact that after the main quest line there is no free roam.   SPOILER:After Lassard has go you collect the I.D decryptions  just before Marshall has you activate the Ark Capsules  be sure to get all of your exploring and side quests in. After you leave wellsprings for the resistance you can go back to the other settlements at any time, prior to the last mission. As stated I advise you do for the full experience.

content:
Posted: May 6, 2013
												 For years many First-Person shooter RPG Hybrids taken place in some wasteland has been for many of us just a regular tradition each year. With the release of Fallout and even earlier games have made it fun; Rage took up the reins of 2011 for the wasteland First-Person shooter game. Does it stack up as good as the others such as Fallout? Or would it be lost forever, post-apocalyptic style?Story/Design: The story goes that in 2029 the real life meteorite Apophis is on a direct collision mark with Earth and nearly causes mass extinction; however with the world taking precautions they start to send out volunteers in Arks with cryo-genetic hibernation. It didn't go so well, and you are the only survivor of your own particular Ark. After 106 years off that, you step out in the world for the first type, post-apocalypse...Sound familiar? Anyway, the game starts out with a great starting cinematic, yet the story is only decent, if not weak. It takes time that you can try and change the story in general and find out what exactly happened to all the other Arks. The starting point is extremely slow and it took me real motivation to try and push through it in the first hours and not completely stop the game. . Furthermore, just before the game starts to heat up and get you interested it abruptly ends. The ending is certainly jarring (and extremely disappointing) it could serve as a quality story based DLC. The game is quite beautiful though, it honestly depends on your PC though, just like any other game. With the new id tech 5 engine they say it doesn't use any of the same textures twice which is nice; however, this means that your graphics will change once you rotate the camera and will load in accordingly. This can mean textures take in at least a full second or two to load in and can make some gamers lag. It's beautiful, but as a closer look in towns you realize how fuzzy and low-style they are. Overall, I'd like to get this through to everyone, if you're buying Rage then you should NOT be buying it for the story, it's slow and disappointing and forgettable. The textures are nice while driving around, yet in towns it can a whole second or two to load in at least a simple one.Gameplay/Mechanics: This is obviously a First-Person shooter. And I'd like to say that this is a game based off its shooting mechanics and it does a fantastic job of it. It feels smooth enough and has multiple guns to choose from. The game is also a RPG mixed game, obviously trying to take from other wasteland style of games, but is nowhere near as complex as say Fallout, or even a few mechanics of Borderlands. It results in using different type of ammo, selling and trading items, building things with objects for opening doors and other objects. It's simple yet does well. It also has quests and side quests to do multiple things along with just running around, killing, or just collecting. Racing and vehicle combat is also a big part of the game, races are critical to upgrading your vehicle. The driving controls are odd though, realistic they are not and you must keep using it to feel comfortable behind the wheel. The FPS feel is great and well done, the RPG elements are simple yet for some groups can be just what they want, with more experienced RPG players it will seems a bit too simplistic for them. The vehicle combat is actually fun and is a key thing from the game. It's a fun game to play but as I said, just to play, not to hear about the story.Rage is a game not based on story; it tries and fails with disappointment. The combat and gameplay is fun and engaging. The wasteland is beautiful yet with the hiccups it might seem like an aesthetic blemish to some, yet game breaking for others. It's an above-average FPS shooter, but it's just that. Slightly above average, the same bland story as some, and not memorable as I had to force and push myself to get through it. If you want a good FPS, without good story then you can try to get this on sale. If you want story...you're going to need to find something else. 6.8/10

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												For me the only frustrations that arose with RAGE surrounded the fact that it comes so close to greatness.  A troubled PC launch seemed to kill the multiplayer community and the DLC adds little to the experience.  Yet even the limp ending and slim illusion of player freedom cannot hide the fact that ID know all about shooting things in the face.  That is where the fun is to be had in this game; shoot all of the things, then throw spiderbots, turrets and boomerangs into the mix.  The world and character design are enjoyable, although you never really interact with them in a meaningful way.  Whilst the racing and mini games are briefly entertaining, they prove to be little more than resource grinding.  RAGE also harbours RPG and crafting pretensions that do not get in the way, but feel strangely unimportant as a result.  If any one of these elements worked as well as the shooting, ID would have been on to a real winner here.  Just imagine what this could have been like if they had nailed them all......As it stands, RAGE has a solid core hidden amongst elements that either time, money or skill (all three?) prevented from truly coming together as a whole.  Seven out of ten seems fair, perhaps the ambition sends it a point either side of that mark, depending on how you take to the games weaker elements.  Should ID have focused their effort a little better?  Perhaps; the game shines when played with a controller and employing a gung ho approach to ammo and resource expenditure, as the title would seem to suggest.  It's just a shame that other aspects of the game never hit those heights.

content:
Posted: August 3, 2016
												It was a decent game. To start things off we'll talk about the setting. Rage is set in a post apocalyptic wasteland, the scenery is mostly vallies of stone and sand with remnants off dead trees and various other small flora like dune grasses here and there. Not a whole lot,though it is a desert like setting where water is scarce so it makes sense. The general vibe is very steam punkish with a lot of rust and metals with weapons ranging from modified crossbows to machines to plasma cannons etc.. Indoor settings are mostly tech like and/or mutatant infested sewers or a combination of the two.The graphics were well enough. I played through on medium settings and it looked good and ran rather smooth on my laptop. No blocky square head or hands, the animations weren't clunky and looked proper enough for the actions. The controls were easy enough to get accustomed too ( you can change them anyhow if you don't like them in the settings) and were accurate. They were a bit sensitive though.... During gun fights they were well enough but the cursor on menus was insanly sensitive. Straffing was very fast as well, peaking around corners for stealth turned into full blown assaults very quickly lol. The jump button was pretty pointless as well, I couldn't jump over anything at all in the game and I tried just about everything >.< .Sound was alright along with voice acting. Never had to shove my head into my screen to here characters speak or had stuttered speech. Few well known actors voiced.Haven't played alot of multiplayer yet but from what it seems it is  Racing, V.S, and Team version campaign missions from the game. All in all I loved the game and reccomend it to others. My biggest dislike was the fact that after the main quest line there is no free roam.   SPOILER:After Lassard has go you collect the I.D decryptions  just before Marshall has you activate the Ark Capsules  be sure to get all of your exploring and side quests in. After you leave wellsprings for the resistance you can go back to the other settlements at any time, prior to the last mission. As stated I advise you do for the full experience.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 22, 2014
												While this game has a lot of rough edges and if you do buy it you might want to look up some config or visual modification tools in order to make it work for you the game is well done for the most part.  While it may not be as open as some other FPS/RPG games out there it does bring a few good things to the table that others do not have.  The enemy models, animations and reaction are very well done, fluid and depending on which faction you're fighting against it might play out differently.  NPC interactions are good, and facial animations are very well done making them feel organic at times.  The story is a bit rough in places and if you've read anything about this game you will already know that the ending is well not great to say the least.  While I do wish there was more to the game then what is offered it was mostly fun while it lasted.  The tech in the game world is very nice and refreshing; the in game crafting is rather well done and very quick allowing you to use different items against different enemy types.  The game could have been better, defiantly, the story could have been a bit better and my god the texture pop in is the worst I have ever seen in my life, however it may not have entirely been iD’s fault based on what I’ve read.  Even on current gen systems you will at times get odd FPS loss and major screen tearing and if you have an ATI card you might want to look else where because I have read that people are STILL having trouble running this game.  If you can buy/find it on sale like I did when I got it, it’s well worth the money, especially once you tinker with the game engine to make it look/run a little better.  It’s far better then anything Gearbox has done to date I can honestly say that, it’s not a boring motionless world with singular friendly/peaceful NPCs, however it is no Fallout 3, it is very much in between, far better gun play then FO3 for sure however.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 27, 2015
												I'm a decent way in to the game now - got all the gear, fairly certain where the end game is headed. I definitely have a good feel for the features and style of the game, and while I've selected yes - I do recommend the game - that comes with several important caveats. iD have created a shooter with some really interesting ideas in RAGE. Unfortunately, it suffers from a stunning lack of ideas in many important respects, also - most of which have to do with the actual playing of the game. It's very old fashioned, in many ways, which you may view as a good thing if you're nostalgic for FPS games of old. Weapons assigned to number buttons, 1-10? Check. Unlock them in sequence, just as they're needed? Check. Tight corridors and fast enemies for shotgun splooshing? Check. Open spaces and cover loving baddies for sniper or machine gun play? Check. Oh, and here's a crossbow. Because crossbow. The enemies, while spouting some interesting dialogue, are of very limited variety, models reused with alarming frequency. Likewise, their move sets are limited. The challenge arises here in presenting you with more enemies, or sometimes enemies with higher hit points, than in providing smarter baddies. I can't think of a single interesting villian - or hero, for that matter - in the game so far. The characters are massively cliché. Attempts at making the world intimidating, or even horrifying in terms of things you see in bandit camps, are immediately undone by slapstick bad guys with cartoonish animation. Also, it's always jarring to be lectured endlessly about the dangers of this horrifying world, how every step outside the secure towns is taking your life in your hands as hordes of unspeakable monstrosities await the frothy goodness of your very blood...and then to saunter from place to place on a quad bike or stupidly heavily armed buggy without so much as an insult shouted from a nearby hillock. RAGE is not a dangerous world. Glasgow pubs are, literally and figuratively, more dangerous than RAGE. This is a game with too many ideas, some of which conflict stylistically with each other. And despite, or perhaps because of, the implementation of these ideas, other things are just left to the side. The world is very small, with some areas getting reused numerous times, just filled with different baddies. There's no true free roaming, in that you follow a limited set of canyons to a few major hubs. Occasionally you blow up a dam, or other obstruction, to unlock new canyons and a new hub. Quests are just places to go and collect things, with set pieces all along the way. A little bit on rails for a modern shooter. RAGE also features an incredibly annoying set of outdated features which aren't directly related to the gameplay. ALL the button prompts are for xBox controllers, even if one isn't hooked up. I know it's a console port, but that's just lazy and off-putting, and the mapping for controls is far from explicit about what the assigned key will do. The game actually prompts you to save on some occasions (only seen this in DLC missions so far, to be fair), stating that "The action is about to HOT up, better save". Any immersion you managed to achieve in this game, you just shattered with one pop-up. It may sound like griping, but the menu is just plain silly. Select quit game...get the "Are you sure" message. Select yes...get dumped to the opening splash screen, prompted to press enter. Press enter, get the main menu. Select quit game, and...get the are you sure window *again*. The game also features something worth special mention: The Most Pointless Weapon Upgrade Ever. Yes, the MPWUE can be found right here in RAGE! An otherwise neat little gun, the Authority LMG, features an optic with decent magnification, good accuracy, large magazines, and an armour piercing ammo variety. It's a staple, and it comes in very handy. And you can buy a laser pointer for it. Now this would be fairly useless anyway, as the shotgun takes care of anything short range and for long range - duh, optic. But the laser beam actually fades away within a few virtual inches of the gun. Even if you stand beside a wall, you realise it's just "painted on" - no red dot ever appears. And, and - there's an aiming reticule anyway! Granted, I've never tried disabling it. Maybe you can. Even so, this somewhat expensive upgrade feels like a lot of ideas in this game: it doesn't matter whether it WORKS, we just think it's cool. So why would I recommend RAGE? The vehicle combat between hubs actually feels pretty good. They got the feel and speed very nearly perfect. The weapons, while outlandish and old school, are very fun, especially the alternative ammunition types. Some of the town characters are kind of fun - Kvasir is a favourite, with the little cute robot head on his shoulder nodding or shaking its head along with his conversation. The crafting aspect is pretty well implemented without being intrusive. The little turrets, sentry bots, RC bomb cars and so on, are all fun to scavenge for and use. The areas you go to for missions - should have mentioned, they load up when you enter, they're not part of the open canyons directly - are well laid out, though the path is fairly linear. A little exploration is rewarded with spare parts and such. RAGE kinda sorta tries to be a more action oriented Fallout, but falls way short of the depth and story of that remarkable world. It also tries to be a single player Borderlands, a bit, and that's just absurd. A showcase of great ideas pinned on an ungainly donkey, pick it up cheap, laugh at its absurdity, enjoy smooshing mutants with an arsenal of stuff...but don't expect awe or major adrenaline rushes, nor a deep, post apocalyptic experience.

content:
Posted: August 31, 2014
												First of all, i dont wana teach people how to write reviews or match rating with the written review.. but i must say that imo 2 points out of 10 are a question of personal taste. Not only that, but i must also say that you can review black without knowing white, same goes for saying x is great if y doesnt exist... this means that rating is possible and legit when you compare to other games in its category or atleast with similarities... With this said... i give this game a 10 and i am surprised with the low rating and reviews...Where can i start? well with the fact that, this is a bethesda game... so to those complaining about graphics.. they are perfect to me.. if you want a game to escape your CoD or Battlefield addiction dont low rate a good quality game just because graphics arent similar... On the same road, i must say that i am surprised that this marvelous fps game is from bethesda, since they are renowned for their rpgs. So it was indeed a great positive surprise for me...The shooting is great, the combat smooth, the whole idea of wasteland violence and surprise attacks is just... 10... right of the bat i got spooked out with a bandit jumping on me. The fact that ammo keeps running low is also good imo, since it adds to the difficulty (which may i say, scales awesomely well... hard to see a fps with such a great difficulty scaling(usually its either dumb dummies or headshot bots))The vehicle combat is really fun and interesting. Side quests (even though it is not an rpg) exist and are great.helpful and fun...Now... to all negative reviews.. i just gota say that, ofcourse you cant compare this game to cod or battlefield.. this game has a great story, and alot more than mere shooting, its bethesda... Comparing it to fallout is also silly, even though both are bethesda and involves wastelands, 1 is a rpg and the other fps with little rpg elements. I must say that this is also a great point for this game, the rpg elements are genious... they are just enough to maintain fps status but still give some extra stuff to do and work on.This game cannot be compared to Stalker also... Stalker is also fps true, but has way more elements of rpg.. Its a great game also, BUT simply cannot be compared to RAGE. Whole different ideas, 1 has intense combat which is cohesive to the fact that you are being hunted down, the other is honest and loyal to the idea that you are a stalker... and therefore is just existing like other stalkers (scavenging)Compare this game to metro last light... which as i reviewed... is really really unfinished. Compare both games... both fps, both of them are post apocalyptical games and both pursue the idea of intense combat. However... metro has no side quests, no minimum rpg elements... many strings that you pull only to realise there is nothing on the other end...Rage does have a story and its pretty linear... you cant simply cant get lost... if you get lost playing rage.. you should stick to basic left to right games.. STILL it manages to give you room to work on smaller stuff.. Yes the story aint deep... but tell me 5 fps games that get you immersed in its story....I sincerly find it pretty sad, to see critics unable to match their writing to their number rating. Even more to see players and pro critics alike comparing this game to cod when it comes to shooting and graphics and story to other bethesda rpg games... seriously... giving metro last joke a 8 and this game a 4.8 user rating is just ridiculous.... If you played stalker or metro the joke and like post apocalyptical fps games... Rage is an awesome surprise... dont trust ratings from people who compare it wrongly... just give it a chance... its bethesda ffs.... ID made great game aswell... why on earth wouldnt you try it?Oh and to all bug this.. crash that... graphic that" seriously... people dont downvote jokes like darksouls for its pathetic almost unplayable pc version but will downvote this because it has better graphics on console?!? ilogical imo... The game runs fine... if by any chance you think its lagish due to low fps, press esc, go to options and there you shall find video options that you can change... judging by what i see on many reviews, this is apparently really hard to do...

content:
Posted: August 11, 2013
												RAGE is an extremely fun shooter with a lot of fun weapons,impressive AI,and it makes great use of its somewhat limited level design by throwing interesting enemies at you,like those dudes who run on the walls and grab stuff on the ceiling and will even roll on the ground to avoid your fire.It's one of the very few good modern shooters.The health regen isn't even a handicap to the game,because there is lenty of cover and you don't have to wait for long.I might add that your view doesn't spaz out up and down like in most horrible modern first person shooters.AND YOU ARE NOT FORCED TO ONLY CARRY 2 WEAPONSThe fighting feels visceral,the animations are brilliant,there is a lot of blood and gory headshots,and when enemies explode,they leave a big splat of blood and tiny gibs go everywhere,painting the walls red.The driving aspect of the game is neither fun or interesting,and the races are absolute uninspired garbage and seems to have been thrown in there at the last minute.You'll spend your time between cool epic firefights driving back home to get new missions,and then driving to said missions.With random events like meteors made out of goodies that fall in front of you and you have to catch them.Or bandits you can fight,but it's not nearly as interesting.The vehicles only have 2 weapons,and the game auto locks on an enemy for you.They happen way too often and you should have the option to only make them spawn when you want,or be able to teleport back to town.The story is not really interesting,and gets buried deep underground by the annoying voice acting.It's not badly voiced,but it's pointless.The game takes 5 minutes to tell you ''good job,here is reward.''And you can't skip the dialogs.(or in this case,monologs) so you have to run backwards until the NPC stops talking and come back to him to hear the next part,and keep repeating this until you can finally accept the mission.One of its biggest qualities is the the level design.It's not just the ''point A => cutscene QTE cutscene QTE hide shoot hide shoot cutscene QTE point B end'' formula.There are no cutscenes during fights.Or annoying QTEs.That deserved to be said.The game uses fairly open linear levels,with a bit of exploration.The ''open world'' isn't really that open or that big,but it doesn't affect the game in a negative way.I still wonder how fun it could have been to roam around a huge map,enter a random building,and have super fast paced firefights.There is a little bit of RPG in this game,as you can collect junk,sell it,and craft stuff.Like some kind of door opening thing that will open locked doors that lead to stuff for you to get and sell/use to shoot baddies.You can also craft RC cars that go boom.Overall it's an amazing shooter with small problems that you can easily overcome.And it has fun coop!

content:
Posted: January 8, 2016
												Let's start immediately with the only thing I didn't like: weak finale. Really? Come on Id, you've a long list of weak finales (quake, quake2,doom3 was better though) but this is probably the weakest.Ok. Cons list done. Apart from that, Rage is probably a MASTERPIECE. You start being an old-era apocalypse survivor and, before you have enough time to understand what's happening you're diving in a BEAUTIFUL post-apocalyptic HUGE scenario. A world, so various that goes from broken highways to dead cities, filthy sewers and many many more.Graphics, The detail is UNBELIEVABLE, every single aspect of every map is placed carefully and planned deeply. You can almost smell the garbage in wasted garage or gasoline in Shrouded Bunker. It's awesome how level designers pay attention to every single insignificant detail. Beautiful. I didn't see any popping artifacts, I must say, Probably because my video card is very old engine just decides to use low texture by default (most of all in Dead City level apparently), which it's ok for me.Gameplay, It's id, come on, Obviously the best in town. Every shot you fire it seems that really hurts enemies, and their bodies react with damage + previous movement so it really seems that a running mutant, coming after you, after been shot to death, has still some inertia to die in front of you making two more steps. This is art, imo.I noticed they add a little "RPG" addition, like the possibility to buy / sell items and to create objects from blueprints but developers decided that, very wisely imo, this is an FPS and has to remain an FPS, so this is the only "non FPS" insertion they added.Environment. Various, huge, well detailed. East and west waste land differ very much one from the other.Open Word. The entire game level is open, sure. But, during missions, you've the sensation that there's only one way to finish the mission and one way to follow to reach the end of the level but, it's done so beautifully that imo is a pro and not a con.Summary. I really don't see a reason why not to buy (maybe in sale if it's possible) this masterpiece from ID Software. If new Doom will be at least 40% good as Rage, it will be awesome!!

												Rage was a much better game than it got credit for. Smooth gun play, beautiful backdrops, and relatively enjoyable NPCs. However, it took heat for a few, notable reasons: First, at launch it was a buggy, ♥♥♥♥♥tormed MESS of a game! Second, the end of the game feels like a friggen "mid-point" in the story arc - but nope, that's the ending. And third: The Id Tech 5 engine has issues with particle textures. That being said, up close things don't always looks so amazing.All and all, the game IS good, it just wasn't good ENOUGH. I'd say I feel this game needs a "meh" or "alright" thumbs rating more thant "good" or "bad". If it's on sale, and you like the Fallout type of world (this is similar in some ways), this is worth your time to mess around with if anything else. 4.99 or 8.99 would be fair prices

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 8, 2016
												Let's start immediately with the only thing I didn't like: weak finale. Really? Come on Id, you've a long list of weak finales (quake, quake2,doom3 was better though) but this is probably the weakest.Ok. Cons list done. Apart from that, Rage is probably a MASTERPIECE. You start being an old-era apocalypse survivor and, before you have enough time to understand what's happening you're diving in a BEAUTIFUL post-apocalyptic HUGE scenario. A world, so various that goes from broken highways to dead cities, filthy sewers and many many more.Graphics, The detail is UNBELIEVABLE, every single aspect of every map is placed carefully and planned deeply. You can almost smell the garbage in wasted garage or gasoline in Shrouded Bunker. It's awesome how level designers pay attention to every single insignificant detail. Beautiful. I didn't see any popping artifacts, I must say, Probably because my video card is very old engine just decides to use low texture by default (most of all in Dead City level apparently), which it's ok for me.Gameplay, It's id, come on, Obviously the best in town. Every shot you fire it seems that really hurts enemies, and their bodies react with damage + previous movement so it really seems that a running mutant, coming after you, after been shot to death, has still some inertia to die in front of you making two more steps. This is art, imo.I noticed they add a little "RPG" addition, like the possibility to buy / sell items and to create objects from blueprints but developers decided that, very wisely imo, this is an FPS and has to remain an FPS, so this is the only "non FPS" insertion they added.Environment. Various, huge, well detailed. East and west waste land differ very much one from the other.Open Word. The entire game level is open, sure. But, during missions, you've the sensation that there's only one way to finish the mission and one way to follow to reach the end of the level but, it's done so beautifully that imo is a pro and not a con.Summary. I really don't see a reason why not to buy (maybe in sale if it's possible) this masterpiece from ID Software. If new Doom will be at least 40% good as Rage, it will be awesome!!

content:
Posted: July 9, 2015
												One of the most beautiful & horrible looking game I've ever seen. Looks great until it comes under scrutiny. I bought this on sale for very cheap since I ignored it on release because of it's early issues. I found it to be a solid FPS with some great driving mechanics (although driving didn't really rock my boat). Not a bad story and a couple of wow moments. The ending, although poor, looks to feed into part 2 so I would've forgiven it.. I can't see Rage 2 coming, so unforgiven :)Buy Rage when it's 3 or 4 quid and it's bob on.I did speed to the end as I had something else on the go, still took me 16 hours to push the main story. I would have gone back to finish the side quests if I'd got the option but the game denies you access once the credits roll, DLC fixes this I am told and even more DLC gives you a better and more fitting endgame.All in all; fair to good, 7 lollipops out of 10.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 9, 2015
												In this game you can carry 10 weapons (and probably unlimited ammo)  and shoot mutants along with  high-tech supersoldiers in a postapocalyptic world. You can also be a race driver with your very own cars. Pro:The combat system is excellent (these guys made the Doom series..), and I must mention, that the enemy death and combat  animations are exemplary. If I shoot somebody in the stomach, he falls to the ground, then drags himself to the nearest cover, and prepares to die. But he's still alive, so until then, shoots some bullet at you. If I hit somebody's feet, it limps, like in reality. You can be an engineer and construct items such as sentry bots and turrets. These bots are overpowered in my opinion, you can spawn 2 at the same time, and they clear the area for you. The races are exciting, but won the first place always at the first try. The minigames are also cool. Never facede any bugs (fell off the map once, but it was my fault). Contra:However, you can't really jump. Apart from the race fields, the whole game is very linear. You go into a building through the front door,  kick some♥♥♥♥♥inside, then return to that door again. And almost every single mission is like this.  The characters are boring, but their mimics and gestures are detailed. The textures sometimes look correct, but when they don't, they're ugly and low detailed. You have to save manually, because the game saves only at the beginning and the end of the mission. Forgot that when I started, and had to start again a mission. This game offers much more then 25 hours of content, in overall, it's a great FPS. If it has 75% off, or more, don't hesitate, buy it!

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 16, 2014
												So I'm gonna try to keep this short and sweet.I really liked this game it was a great FPS with more ways to kill than just unloading into a guy the weapon selection and execution was one of the best I have ever seen and the way your enemies react to them is perfection.The story is linear but it's done the right way and keeps you pretty well immersed in the game the side missions are fun but do get a bit repetitive.The graphics are decent, My PC is no where near that great so it was a little rough for me but not game breaking and the controls are great I played mostly with a gamepad but did use the mouse and keyboard some as well.The mani complaint I have about the game is the ending, the final battle wast really anything special I expected something pretty big after talking to NPC's and given the gun I was given was ridiculously huge but it was quite a let down when the fight was over and the cutscene started. As for the ending cutscene it was good and I did like it but I wish they would have shown more and explained it better and also acknowledged the fact that you had beaten The Authority after it goes back to the game to let you finish anything you wanted to do.All in all the game was great and I really liked it despite the ending seeming like they just wanted to be done with it.I do reccomend it to anyone that likes the FPS and post apocalptic style games as his was a different spin on a great genre.8/10and so mch for short and sweet oh well

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 29, 2012
												This game shows off what id does best: technology and shooting.  As an FPS, it's top notch.  The guns feel great and the enemy AI is fantastic.  Each type of enemy behaves differently and gives you nice variety throughout the game.  When you go out into the open world, the vehicles feel great and combat is solid.  id also did a great job modestly expanding their usual game archetype with driving, missions, and crafting.  And most surprising, the voice acting, sound, and music are top notch.On the technology side, it is nothing short of groundbreaking.  It had a rough launch mostly due to driver issues which have since been resolved;  Now everybody can enjoy the entirely hand-painted world (check out my screenshots).  Of course the downside is, since every texture is unique, things don't look so great close-up.  But I choose to enjoy the game rather than look for faults and it's just amazing my computer can crank out 60 fps when it looks so good.Just don't expect a fantastic story.I'd also like to add how impressed I am with the DLC.  It costs $5 and has more content than most $10 DLCs while maintaining the same high quality as the rest of the game.  id managed to integrate the DLC seamlessly with the rest of the story so you never feel like you're actually playing a DLC.  The only real change is that the DLC content is significantly harder than most of the rest of the game.  I highly recommend it to anyone who enjoyed RAGE.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2013
												I have read pretty much everything and its opposite about that game. So I wanted to write a review, to try to give a comprehensive list of the pros/cons of that game.First of all, this game is NOT a Role Playing Game. Of course, like every single game, it can fit into its definition, since you play the role of a character in an imaginary world. Now, it is not what is conventionally accepted as a RPG. This game has no character levels, it has no skills, it has no skill-tree either of course, and so on.This game is a shooter. By the people who invented the genre, id Software. Now, if it is from the people who invented the genre, how can it only have a User Score of "49" (at the time of writing) on metacritic? The reason is simple: this game is really different from what id Software usually does (or did. I did not play, by far, all the id Software shooters; but I played Doom and Quake).So, what are the pros and the cons?Pros:The overall experience is rather original, refreshing, with a definitely solid and consistent shooter feeling (think of other id Software games, the weapon handling is really close to that). The id Tech 5 graphical engine is incredibly slick, does a wonderful job, and even if the textures are sometimes ugly, or even horrible, when inspected from up close; the game has really neat graphics.In addition, the world, even if not so deep (remember, this is by no mean a RPG), has some interesting aspects, and the artists did an unbelievable job making each part of it unique and authentic.Cons:id Software used to do PC games. For a company that pretty much invented the FPS genre, it was perfectly logical. Whereas I can understand why publishers decide to make every single game available on consoles, it still is a mystery for me when developers also take that direction. Not for all games, of course, Mario and Sonic were totally fitting for consoles, and so were many arcade games I played as a kid.But for FPSes, one can only wonder. I know that the fingers are probably the most precise appendices we have, but even; how can someone imagine to replace two hands with five and three fingers (for the keyboard and the mouse respectively), plus one arm (the mouse movement has more amplitude, and therefore, more precision, than a stick) by only four fingers (thumbnails and indexes), for the same result?And even if id Software managed (thanks to their extensive experience?) not to get the main gameplay cluttered by such a decision, ALL the rest of the game has been affected. Not only the interfaces.And the game also features some mandatory races, there are achievements for random games (random achievements? what's next, unobtainable achievements?), and trying to 100% the game will be an incredibly frustrating experience, for those reasons.It's also worth mentioning that the difficulty is somewhat low (that goes with the "console" aspect I presume: the game has to be accessible to as many people as possible), or at best inconsistent (the Scorchers DLC increased the difficulty a bit, but also gives the nail gun, which has an unlimited ammo (rebar) and a rail gun mode, allowing to see the enemies in advance, and even to kill them without exposing yourself), even in ultra nightmare (which is turning the game into a binary experience (who shoots first) rather than into a harder one), and that in spite of the obvious efforts to make the game as non-linear as possible; all the missions are constructed with the scheme: talk to X, go to Y, kill all the baddies along the way.Bottom line:The game still is worth some money, as it has a strong shooter feeling, various encounters, an awesome atmosphere. But don't expect the usual id Software FPS, it is not.Additional Note:I got an "Anarchy edition" (the pre-order bonus) key in order to get all the additional content. I would recommend to do the same, or at least, to unlock the pre-order content (there is a console command for that) when you play the game, as it deeply changes the gameplay.

content:
Posted: February 29, 2012
												This game shows off what id does best: technology and shooting.  As an FPS, it's top notch.  The guns feel great and the enemy AI is fantastic.  Each type of enemy behaves differently and gives you nice variety throughout the game.  When you go out into the open world, the vehicles feel great and combat is solid.  id also did a great job modestly expanding their usual game archetype with driving, missions, and crafting.  And most surprising, the voice acting, sound, and music are top notch.On the technology side, it is nothing short of groundbreaking.  It had a rough launch mostly due to driver issues which have since been resolved;  Now everybody can enjoy the entirely hand-painted world (check out my screenshots).  Of course the downside is, since every texture is unique, things don't look so great close-up.  But I choose to enjoy the game rather than look for faults and it's just amazing my computer can crank out 60 fps when it looks so good.Just don't expect a fantastic story.I'd also like to add how impressed I am with the DLC.  It costs $5 and has more content than most $10 DLCs while maintaining the same high quality as the rest of the game.  id managed to integrate the DLC seamlessly with the rest of the story so you never feel like you're actually playing a DLC.  The only real change is that the DLC content is significantly harder than most of the rest of the game.  I highly recommend it to anyone who enjoyed RAGE.

content:
Posted: June 8, 2016
												Rage is a first-person shooter set in a post-apocalyptic world that offers plenty of enemies to shoot, and a variety of other mini games to play.As far as the world is concerned, there will definitely be a lot of comparisons to Borderlands. It is certainly a darker, and grittier version of that world, but it is less expansive and even less characterful than Borderlands. Also, the game tries to progress the story through a series of quest-givers to make it feel even more like Borderlands, however without any of the RPG elements such as character progression, talent trees, or loot, it seems out of place. In fact, because there are no RPG elements, the story could have been presented in a much more immersive way. The game tries to add in other diversions to make the world feel more immersive. Crafting allows you to create various gadgets and weapons, but you can easily get through the game without crafting anything. Often, it is simply easier to just buy whatever you want instead of crafting it. There are a variety of mini-games, including a card game where you can collect cards found throughout the world. However, not everyone in this world plays it. In fact, only a very few NPCs play this game, and they can be beat without finding all the "best" cards, so it takes the incentive away from trying to hunt down the cards. The game also tries to shoehorn in a driving aspect and even lets you upgrade all the parts of the vehicle: and you can only get these upgrades through a currency you get from racing. But in the end, the racing is not really challenging nor particularly fun. So finally, that leaves the shooting element of the game. There are certainly many enemies to shoot in this game. But none of your guns seem to pack a visceral punch. They don't sound or feel strong enough, and even when at point blank range with a shotgun, most average-grunt enemies still require 2 to 3 shots to down. All-in-all, Rage is a game that has many dimensions, but none of them are fleshed out particularly well. If you are a fan of first person shooters, you may find some interest in playing through this title, but it's certainly not going to be a title you will have a great experience playing, nor will it be particularly memorable. It's pretty much the definition of "middle of the road."5/10 "Mediocre"

content:
Posted: January 30, 2014
												At every possible moment this game threatens to become a good shooter.  There's really no reason it shouldn't be.  It's got a gorgeous graphics engine, entertaining guns... what else do you need?  Oh right.  What we don't have here is pacing, good level design or interesting enemies.  On top of that the game just decides to end at one arbitrary point.  On my first playthrough I got through the whole game without ever firing the game's 'super weapon'.  I was saving it for a climactic boss fight or final level that never actually came.Too easy, as well.  I played through on nightmare and felt no sense of accomplishment having beaten it whatsoever.

Posted: October 8, 2014
												I would definitely recommend buying this game. It has a very Mad Max vibe and provided hours of entertainment. There is a standard FPS weapon spread (pistol, shotgun, SMG, AR, etc) and a fair variety of enemies to shoot at. I found the story to be standard post apocalypse fair but this games take on it is good. There is a decent amount of sidequests and even some races both with and without weapons to provide some more thrills. Vehicles and weapons can be customized as the story progresses. There is also decent multiplayer based off events that take place during campaign to keep you going after the campaign is finished.

content:
Posted: December 24, 2016
												(review for single-player only)RAGE is a strange game. It's a mash-up of different scenarios that doesnt really fit together. It's one part Combat Cars Racing game, one part Mad Max, one part Steam, one part Zombie fps and a small but significant part sci-fi. If the dev's had only stuck to one or two and then really seen that through, it would have been great.The mechanics are good, the main story is ok to a start, side stories and quests are easy to find and do, character progression is ok, but not great but somewhere in mid-game, the devs just stopped working and the result is not what the game could have been.Too bad really, I really liked it the first hrs.It's not really a bad game, I just got really disapointed after awhile.Buy it on sale if you wanna shoot stuff in a mad max futuristic steamish world, and race cars at the same time.
