content:
Posted: October 3, 2014
												There is a lot of things I dislike about this game, but I still quite enjoy playing it. But there is some things that just irritates me about it. Let's start of with what I dislike.Negative:*You do not have an in-game town/world map, kind of sucks cause I'm one of those guys who likes to explore everything and check off certain areas as "done" with memorizing the areas through world map. On the other hand the game seem to be so linear that you don't need one.*The jump seems worthless, there are obstacles in the game that's not even up to your knees that you can't jump across, which makes me think "why did they even give you the option to use jump at all?". You can't even climb over desks, or big windows with stuff in it, you have to get a lock grinder or whatever it's called to blow up the door. That's so poor.*A headshot with the crappy pistol doesn't kill the enemy, not even 1 feet away. A bullet through the skull on a human being should kill him. (And no, I do not mean the guys with helmets)*The co-op was a bit dissapointing and really short, I was expecting being able to play full campaign with my brother and not some short missions. Maybe I did my research badly before purchasing the game.*Using bandages or creating them seem to be quite useless. I mean you do regenerate full health by just not getting shot anwyay and if you badly need a bandage you're probably screwed over anyway cause you need to swap to the bandages from whatever you're currently using, like HE grenades or whatever. A heal button is missed in those scenarios, like pressing "H" on your keyboard.*The mouse feels bad when you're in the menu, checking inventory, quests and things like that. Feels like it's lagging.*In combat you can't lean!! I hate that you can't lean and take cover, best you can do is to crouch behind a desk or things a like and just stand up to shoot and then sit again. I think it's rreally poor that you can't lean when your opponents can do all kind of stuff, lean, jump over desks, climb though windows, take their arm up with gun only shooting at you while taking cover.Postive:*The vehicles looks good and are fun to drive.*The FPS is overall nice, except you can't lean!*The enviroments and graphics are okay for being a couple of years old game, don't see why people complain over it really.*The enemies move good and make up for the lack of leaning.*Quests are OK.Overall, there is more negative things to say about the game then positive.I would recommend this game at a low price on sale, but no chance of getting it at it's full price, there for I do NOT recommend buying this game. It kills some time sure, but if you're out after a good fps game, spend your money on something else.

content:
Posted: June 12, 2015
												Just another spam spawning, bullet sponge rail shooter with mediocre graphics and AI.Honestly, Rage is a step backward from the 2009 release of Wolfenstein.As with every other iD installment, area triggers spam in mobs, even in areas you just cleared. The term "one clip, one kill" applies here, as mobs which aren't mutants will require a full magazine pumped into them to take them down. It takes a minimum of two head shots from the sniper rifle, which is just a forced waste of ammo. One human enemy in white armor took 3 and 1/2 magazines of ammo to drop, and that was at 5 paces using short controlled bursts so no bullets missed. It was not a boss, but just a trash mob bad guy.Graphics.I keep seeing people praising the graphics of this game, but cannot see why. I got it shortly after it was released, and even then it was sub par compared to other titles. Sure, outdoor scenes can look quite picturesque overall, but the moment you get near any items, their mediocre look really shows. It's as if, even when on the highest graphics settings, that Mipmap number 2 is being used. Some items in the game haven't even been properly UVW mapped, so they just have distorted, splotchy pixels on them. I feel this is a symptom of iD being bought out by Bethesda. Several of us had been discussing whether Bethesda would bring iD down, or iD would bring Bethesda up back when iD was acquired. Unfortunately, Bethesda won, and iD's quality has suffered.Maybe it's due to the game being a port, but that is just breaking the 8th commandment of good game development and not an excuse for releasing a bad looking game on the PC.Gameplay and AI.The game handles like your average iD game. Mouse wheel through some of the guns (have to hit the numbers on the keyboard to access the rest), shoot spamming mobs of respawning bad guys, run out of ammo and punch the rest to death while strafing backward. Grab quest item and repeat. The formula worked better in the original Doom.The AI seems like it wants to work, but frequently just starts bouncing bad guys around until you Whack-A-Mole them to death one or two bullets at a time. After an hour in game, it becomes apparent that the AI is sorely lacking, and the game becomes painfully redundant and predictable. Maybe I just played too many iD titles over the decades.If you like redundant rail shooters with mediocre graphics, AI and love spamming hordes coming and going, then grab this game. If you want any kind of sophistication or thought provoking gameplay, avoid it like the plague.After thought.iD attempted to include aspects of all types of genres, and did manage to mix them together well. They even included card games. So you have rail shooter, racing/demolition derby, platformer/killhouse, Magic cards all in one game. I don't play Magic or Borderlands because I don't like Magic or Borderlands. I bought Rage because I thought I was getting another Doom style experience according to their hype. Nope.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 22, 2016
												First things first.  If you do not like arcade style play do NOT buy this game!  There are certain sections early on that require arcade play and a must win (Dusty 8 Race) before you can progress any further.  If you can't hammer away at these sections you're done playing the game (which is where I am now).The FPS portion of the game is great.  Fun weapons and very challenging.  It is unfortunate that many encounters are proximity triggered so there's not as much sneaking up on the enemy as I personally prefer.  Great for those 'run in and kill' player style folks though.The monetary system is a bit of a challenge early on, but as with most games it gets easier.  Some of the side betting games in Wellsprings help.  On the downside, I think there are too many games within the game.  They're nice distractions I guess, but they don't lend to the storyline (as far as I got that is).The explorable world is really not all that big.  This is not some large open map, but rather a nicely textured backdrop in which missions are narrowly bracketed into the surrounding landscape.  It takes little to no time to find the outer boundaries of the map in each mission.  No climbing over the boulders, sneaking around, and getting the lay of the land before you proceed around that blind curve... you're just gonna have to proceed. In as much as the previous mission areas remain open, creating an ever expanding environment... "vast" hardly describes your gameplay area.The flexibility in assigning key controls is good.  I prefer to keep as much as possible on the keypad and the number of commands allows things to fit nicely.  The graphics are beautiful.  The responsiveness in game (on my machine anyway) is great!I can't recommend the game though.  The game description does not accurately reflect the limitations in play and as I noted previously, there's no clear mention of game stops at arcade style missions much less mention of arcade play at all.  Had I known they existed I would never have purchased the game.  After a mixed bag of high enjoyment in FPS and extreme disappointment and frustration in arcade play the game will be unloaded and placed in the virtual trashcan.There are those that will greatly enjoy the mix of play.  To you I tip my hat!

Posted: April 28, 2012
												An ideal game for someone like me. Non linear in most places, linear in some, story driven, GREAT characters, even greater animations, solid gameplay + good focus on combat.The game is immense. It really plays as good as it looks and that's rare in most games. The levels are vast and detailed and the weapons and gadgets are loads of fun to upgrade and play around with. There's a good mix of linear and non linear gameplay which means that there's an equal amount of attention to the story and the rpg aspect (rpg's usually have a not so deep story).Although it's post apocalyptic, it's seriously original and the detailed environments and genuine atmosphere prove this. I cannnot believe only 7 people on my friends list have this game! :D9/10 (because no game can be completely perfect ^_^)

content:
Posted: October 13, 2011
												I don't know, Rage isn't all that bad. The game does look great, but there are so many technical issues that prevented me from truly enjoying it. The fact that V-sync, at first, wasn't implemented was a bad choice. The texture pop-in was awful as well. Combine this with the freezing problem (every few minutes the game freezes for at least 1-2 seconds) and I'm sure you'll understand what I mean.The gameplay itself is like any other shooter. With some added RPG elements. You'll  collect a lot of worthless junk (which is a shame) and complete simple, sometimes fun, quests. But since there is no real reward for the sidequests there isn't much incentive to do them at all. You'll gain money and some licenses for your vehicle, but no weapons, schematics or anything else. Not even XP. So in the end there's no feeling you're getting any stronger. A missed opportunity. The driving segments are actually ok, but quite easy.Anyway, I did have fun with it, but I expected more to be honest.[Rating: 81/100]

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 19, 2013
												The best way I can sum up Rage is... if you are interested in playing Rage, you've already played this game. It is the next generic post-apocolypse shooter. It's like the sampler appetizer that has just a little bit of pieces of other games. However, this is the best looking of these games. Some of the textures look like total crap, but some areas and vistas look very nice. The game does take a lot of hard drive space for a fairly short game. Overall, it wasn't bad. It took around 13 hours to finish. The story is generic. Most of the combat is done in linear corriders. I didn't care for the hit detection when shooting enemies. Shoot them once and you gotta wait to shoot them again or the hit won't register. A lot of bullets and time were wasted having to wait through the AI recovery  god frame animations so the next bullet will register. Most of the exploration is done with vehicles that let you travel the map. I'd recommend getting Rage if it's on sale and you want some mindless fun. It is unremarkable in every way, but I still managed to have some fun with it.

content:
Posted: January 8, 2014
												I really wanted to hate RAGE, but I couldn't help having a fun time anyway. From the feeling that its a tech demo first and a half hearted entry into a new franchise second, this game is one of missed opportunities and shows how far behind the competition id Software has gotten when it comes to designing memorable experiences. Blurry textures and pop in are a small price to pay when you realize how beautiful and revolutionary MegaTexture streaming actually is from a technical standpoint. On the artistic front there's some truly standout character design and setpieces, but again, they're used only as excuses for shooting galleries. I suspect the lukewarm reception to RAGE stems from people expecting something along the lines of an open-world RPG with idTech behind it: an amazing proposition indeed, but not what this game actually is. It's a punchy shooter with amazing animation (seriously, shoot a bandit and watch him dance) with the smallest concessions to RPG design, paired with a surprisingly robust vehicular combat component. The plot is shockingly thin, unresolved and downright lazy towards the final act. The game does more of its world building through visual shorthand rather than exposition, and its cliched post-apocalypse is better at conveying pixels and polygons than real heart and soul.You'd never mistake this for Borderlands or Fallout, and while it lacks the variety and breadth of its distant cousins, it's still very much its own experience, and one that's worth playing through at least once (and probably only once).

content:
Posted: January 6, 2015
												So i finished RAGE for a third time, finally on steam as perfect game. Great idea of story, only shame they nailed end like that. Storyline has medium lenght (approx. 25hr), couple of sidequests, not very exciting, basically, just repeating already completed location reversed etc. I really want to appeal on main story quests environment and sceneries and hardest game difffficulty, its quite hard from beginning (like death on 2-3 hits, need to be very carefull), but right after purchasing first, second armor upgrade its basic game difficulty.Next BIG plus is ARENA, RACING and MINIGAMES, especially minigames are very funny and challenging.Graphic is a bit less anime than Borderlands, so haters of BL dont be scared of it. More music would be appreciated.Multiplayer - Racing and derby would be fun, but no one plays it.CO-OP missions are very funny, BIG plus for the maps of coop missions (Wellspring street fights, or reversed demolished arena etc.).DLCs - Scorchers dlc is very worthy, contains big storyline, new, freaking OP weapon (Ultra nightmare difficulty is a bit easier from the beggining with that gun), and hard enemies. Also very hot lead character Sarah <3 xDAchievements - Perfect game could be done in one run (only Jetpack achievement requires lower difficulty). I dont like MP racing achievements (2) where u need to be in four players (coop achievements /4/ requires only 1 aditional player), and since nobody plays it, theres just chance u will find someone on steam game discussions. Few PROS- no inventory limit- plenty of zombies (especially sewers missions)- not pointlessly giant map

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2016
												It's unfortunate that RAGE has been subjected to so much negativity. I'm not sure what the origins of it are. Perhaps people expected something different, perhaps people expecting something more on some level because it was the next big game by id. I always loved RAGE. Pretty much everything about it. It plays superbly, being one of the few shooters I've ever played where firing a weapon actually feels powerful and great. It has AI that, while not smart in the sense that FEAR did, they are fun to fight because they move so oddly and realistic at times. I just started playing the new DOOM today and that game is just not for me. Having to search the environment to find something specific is just so boring in that game. I recognize that DOOM just isn't doing something that I like. In the same way I feel that RAGE was subjected to such criticism because it did something a lot of people didn't like. But it is a fantastic game if you like the thing it's going for, because it nails it.(For the record, I played RAGE on 360 when it came out. Intending to play it now on PC, which is why my play time is effectively 0 hours as of this writing).

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 22, 2016
												I acquired RAGE on a sale, and for the price I paid, I'd recommend the experience.  The world is gorgeous, in a post-apocalyptic, Fallout-like style, with some obvious Fallout-like ripoffs.  Still, it's worth it just to experience some of the really immersive visuals.  The characters and people are reasonably good, beautifully crafted, fully voiced with a variety of personalities (even if some of the acting is forced).  Also, the first "Dead City" experience was really memorable.The game is largely good, but suffers from a lack of direction and from trying to do & to be too much.  The crafting system is interesting and provides some value, but largely unnecessary to complete the game.  The various minigames, too, are value-added, but in the same way that finding spare change in your pocket is value-added.  The vehicles actually drive very nicely and are enjoyable, and the vehicular combat isn't bad, but the entire racing circuit side-game is virtually mandatory and--as such--is a detriment.The game is arguably broken up into three sections, by "hub".  The first and third sections are really short, while the second is probably over-long.  The first section, being short, makes sense.  Its an intro to the game; the starting quest hub.  The brevity of the third hub, however, and the entire third section of the storyline--including the anticlimactic end stage and ending--feels shockingly unfinished, especially compared with some real gems in the section section (Wellspring), most notably the first visit to the Dead City.Ultimately, I'd recommend the game, if only to experience the first half to two-thirds of it.

content:
Posted: March 24, 2016
												I like this game. It is a few years old now but the graphics are still fairly good overall. Overall it is a first-person shooter style game, but they added in a driving/racing aspect that not only seems to work fairly well, but to me adds a degree of realism to a post-apocolyptic world that so many other games seem to lack. And unlike some other games, while you can just walk around out on the main map; taking the buggy or the monarch to drive around definitely gets you there both faster and safer. There is a good amount to do in this game aside from the main quest line in the form of side quests and challenges, as well as several easter eggs from the older id software games that are just kinda cool to collect.Now for the bad. Thw game is fairly linear overall. You can miss out on things by progressing the main storyline too far too fast, and I'm not a big fan of that in open-world games. It's not too bad as long as you do optional side quests first then the main 1 but on initial playthrough it might not be obvious. Also, might just be because I'm late to the party, as in I did not buy this game when it was brand new, but there is never anybody on the multiplayer side of this so I can't unlock the rest of my acheivements. not a huge deal, but a little disappointing.Overall, like I said, I really do enjoy the game. I would rate the overall experience as about a 7 out of 10. Definitely worth trying.

From the feeling that its a tech demo first and a half hearted entry into a new franchise second, this game is one of missed opportunities and shows how far behind the competition id Software has gotten when it comes to designing memorable experiences. Blurry textures and pop in are a small price to pay when you realize how beautiful and revolutionary MegaTexture streaming actually is from a technical standpoint. On the artistic front there's some truly standout character design and setpieces, but again, they're used only as excuses for shooting galleries. I suspect the lukewarm reception to RAGE stems from people expecting something along the lines of an open-world RPG with idTech behind it: an amazing proposition indeed, but not what this game actually is. It's a punchy shooter with amazing animation (seriously, shoot a bandit and watch him dance) with the smallest concessions to RPG design, paired with a surprisingly robust vehicular combat component. The plot is shockingly thin, unresolved and downright lazy towards the final act. The game does more of its world building through visual shorthand rather than exposition, and its cliched post-apocalypse is better at conveying pixels and polygons than real heart and soul.You'd never mistake this for Borderlands or Fallout, and while it lacks the variety and breadth of its distant cousins, it's still very much its own experience, and one that's worth playing through at least once (and probably only once).

content:
Posted: October 13, 2011
												I don't know, Rage isn't all that bad. The game does look great, but there are so many technical issues that prevented me from truly enjoying it. The fact that V-sync, at first, wasn't implemented was a bad choice. The texture pop-in was awful as well. Combine this with the freezing problem (every few minutes the game freezes for at least 1-2 seconds) and I'm sure you'll understand what I mean.The gameplay itself is like any other shooter. With some added RPG elements. You'll  collect a lot of worthless junk (which is a shame) and complete simple, sometimes fun, quests. But since there is no real reward for the sidequests there isn't much incentive to do them at all. You'll gain money and some licenses for your vehicle, but no weapons, schematics or anything else. Not even XP. So in the end there's no feeling you're getting any stronger. A missed opportunity. The driving segments are actually ok, but quite easy.Anyway, I did have fun with it, but I expected more to be honest.[Rating: 81/100]

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 28, 2016
												I just finished this plus the DLC and I have to say I enjoyed it quite a lot. It is an amazing FPS experience with a lot more to it than other big FPS games, it's pretty long, with a lot of stuff for you to play around with.I get that numerous people have had technical problems in the past, but most of them didn't at all apply to me, even the infamous texture pop-in wasn't present in my case, with some of the settings tweaked. Even my potato (GT635M) could handle the game at most graphical options high without dropping bellow 35-40FPS.I'd recommend it to anyone looking for a fun, fresh, FPS experience. It's sad that the game was plagued by numerous technical issues upon launch and most people just gave up on it. Just don't go in expecting a more actiony version of Fallout, instead appreciate the effort put into all the different little details and you're gonna have a good time. This isn't an open world game and is quite linear despite giving you the freedom to explore the wasteland. Think of it as an open linear game if that makes sense and I doubt you're going to be disappointed.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 1, 2013
												Hmm what to say...Well at first I saw this game as a Fallout 3/Boardlands rip off. Because of the fact we're in a distopian future, there are vaults and people want to get to the vaults. Game also seems kinda sexist as every woman (apart from elderly woman) I dressed with no tops besides a thin bikini or one-trap bra ann the either wear shorts or jeans in the rare cases.So...good things about the game:*Your weapons have a varied types of ammo such as armour peircing rounds or explosive on some weapons.*The opening of the story is very engaging and interesting, thought your character being a silent protagonist doesn't add to it.*You end up straight into the action, but not in too much of a jarring way.*There are many side-missions and minigames to earn cash such as bulletin board, gambling and others.*You have a crafting system*it's a lot of fun.*You are not stuck to one vehicle and get to change to more advanced ones as you go.However there are many bad parts.*The characters are all quite forgettable*There aren't nearly enough side-missions as Boardlands, which does in a way make it more enjoyable.*The rendering is HIDIOUS. I bought this game late in the date. It's been out for 2 years and they havn't fixed the horrible rendering? If you move around a corner too fast all the textures become blobs and enemies, in a few cases, dissappear until the texture loads up.*There is a lag at times, which means you can miss a good shot or, most frustraitingly, you can mess up at five-fingered fillet.*The story, whilst started strong, has a very lack-luster ending.*Numerous bugs, including a loss of sound leading to watching the end movie on youtube because it cut out and was silent.*Despite your character never been seen in 3rd dimensions apart from end of mutant bash, you cannot customise your character nor does he appear to have a name.*SOME weapons are upgradable, but not many.Over-all it's a fun game and I found myself addicted to playing it, having fun decapitating people with the wingsticks and so on. Despite it's many errors, I would recommend it, if you were just after a fun fps to burn off steam. However if you're looking for something better in storyline then I suggest something more along the lines of Half-life or Portal or even System Shock. It's sad to see Id Software♥♥♥♥♥♥this out with Bethesda. At times there seemed to be good ideas, but at other times they either aren't expanded upon enough or fall flat. Almost like Id Software had a suggestion, Bethesda tried it, then failed misirbly and didn't even put any effort into it.One final thing, this game was obviously made for a controller. You cannot scroll through all your weapons, only 4 pre-sets which, based on the shape, probably are accessable with the D-pad. If anything get this game on a sale and only if you have no other FPSs to play. However there are many funny Id software easter eggs in there :)

												The game isn't terrible, but it has too many faults to be worth buying in this day and age, where we have so many great games out there. -After a certain point in the game, maybe 7 hours in, I started to get dizzy whenever I played it. Boring as ****-It is super linear, and you get no choices anywhere, except for what weapons to use and what upgrades to put on your car.-There is no sensitivity option for your mouse, so you just end up sliding all across the menu, never getting the mouse where you want it to be.It's okay to play and certainly not the worst I've had, but it could have been done so much better. Skip this game.5/10 my lowest rating of all time.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 4, 2016
												Lackluster and anticlimatic are about the right words that can be used to sum up this game.The combat is decent. It's nothing awe inspiring, but it holds its own. The AI seems a little smarter than the norm, as it will allow squads of enemies to work as teams to advance, retreat, or attempt to outflank the player. It has its holes that can be exploited and sometimes does some dumb things, but for the most part provided for satisfying combat.Car combat can be a little frustrating due to clunky controls. It also seems to serve no point other than a novelty or to disguise the game world to seem more open and exansive. It is mostly a boring affair that wouldn't have been missed if it was not in the game.There is an illusion of an open world, but the game areas are actually quite linear. There are many side missions that seem pointless and unrewarding. It probably didn't help that rewards were mysterious and the game is not very forthcoming in communicating what they were. They also tell little about the world you are in. Very thin and bland and could easily be avoided, in favor of sticking with the main mission, without much loss to the experience whatsoever. The game world itself felt rather shallow and it was difficult to relate to or care about anyone or anything within it.Lastly, and probably my biggest gripe, the game just seems to abruptly end in a very anticlimatic fashion. There really wasn't any real main antigonist in the game. You hear rumors and details of the promise of some kind of rival that the player may have to face, but none of it ever comes to fruition. There is never even a single encounter, dialogue, or anything with a supposed main antagonist. The ending of the game lacks any kind of boss encounter at all, even though it leads the player to believe that one should be expected. It's as if the developers ran out of time and resources to flesh out anything the game teases the player with and just abruptly ends. Very lackluster and disappointing, nearly feeling like a waste of time.Only get it if you have a serious hankering for a single player FPS and you've played everything better already. Only get it on sale as well. Or better yet, save your time and play something better.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 6, 2015
												So i finished RAGE for a third time, finally on steam as perfect game. Great idea of story, only shame they nailed end like that. Storyline has medium lenght (approx. 25hr), couple of sidequests, not very exciting, basically, just repeating already completed location reversed etc. I really want to appeal on main story quests environment and sceneries and hardest game difffficulty, its quite hard from beginning (like death on 2-3 hits, need to be very carefull), but right after purchasing first, second armor upgrade its basic game difficulty.Next BIG plus is ARENA, RACING and MINIGAMES, especially minigames are very funny and challenging.Graphic is a bit less anime than Borderlands, so haters of BL dont be scared of it. More music would be appreciated.Multiplayer - Racing and derby would be fun, but no one plays it.CO-OP missions are very funny, BIG plus for the maps of coop missions (Wellspring street fights, or reversed demolished arena etc.).DLCs - Scorchers dlc is very worthy, contains big storyline, new, freaking OP weapon (Ultra nightmare difficulty is a bit easier from the beggining with that gun), and hard enemies. Also very hot lead character Sarah <3 xDAchievements - Perfect game could be done in one run (only Jetpack achievement requires lower difficulty). I dont like MP racing achievements (2) where u need to be in four players (coop achievements /4/ requires only 1 aditional player), and since nobody plays it, theres just chance u will find someone on steam game discussions. Few PROS- no inventory limit- plenty of zombies (especially sewers missions)- not pointlessly giant map

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 10
												I'm kinda split on this game. It's fun, but only in places. It feels somewhat like pulling a cookie out of dirt and trying to eat it. The cookie is still delicious, but it sucks to have to chew dirt. And there isn't a lot of cookie and plenty of dirt. Another analogy, Borderlands without the loot and RPG system, but with slightly better gunplay. Only slightly better.My PC is a bit♥♥♥♥♥♥ so I had a fortune to experience the game the way it was intended: with textures loading out of blurry mess right in front of my eyes (sarcasm alert). Megatextures, and the game's graphics overall, look great in static, but not that great in dynamic. Apart from the aforementioned problem with megatextures, there is a problem with inconsistent quality. Or rather, high quality where it doesn't matter and low quality where it does.  You'll ride by gorgeous canyons and small graffities that you won't even notice, to then have to stare at ugly bushes and muddy wall textures when fighting indoors. The combat is a bit fun. The gunplay feels nice, that's the only thing where I could see the id's fingerprints. Other than that, there isn't much good to say about it. Overall, the combat borrowed too much from cover shooters and was clearly designed for consoles. Guns are underpowered and there seems to be a great reliance on melee and special items.The control scheme is ♥♥♥♥ed, because it was made for consoles. Rebinding doesn't help much. Instead of having separate keys for healthpacks, grenades and wingsticks, they are all grouped as "quick items" and you have to switch between them before using them. And you also have different ammo types that you have to switch between. And you have ADS and melee buttons, which you'll have to use. I don't know why anyone would need healthpacks though. The game uses this atrocious no healthbar, bloody screen, hide to heal system. I thought it has already been prohibited in one of the UN conventions. If it hasn't, it should be. The guns are pretty inaccurate, unless you ADS. The grunts constantly move around and the combat distances are pretty low.  There is a lot of opportunity for melee and a special melee attack button. If you don't use melee, you'll run out of ammo pretty fast, because guns are inaccurate and don't deal a lot of damage, and because the enemies are either behind cover or in a jerky movement. They can also shoot from behind the cover, which you can't do. The classic strafe dance gunfight doesn't work either, because the guns are inaccurate and low damage, enemies move unpredictably and can close the distance rapidly if they want, or hide behind cover and shoot from behind it, and because there isn't much space to strafe around and the floors are uneven so you won't have a steady aim. I think I'm ranting already. If you can try it for free, do it. See if you enjoy it before buying it. I didn't.

												The most disappointing aspect of this game for me is the hit detection on the enemies.  Too often, when my first bullet would hit an enemy they went into an animation telling me they were hit, and then my second bullet seemed to do nothing because it couldn't disrupt the animation. Enemies only ambush you.  Very disappointing for a game by an acclaimed FPS studio.  I wanted to like it but the shooting gameplay was simply not fun.

content:
Posted: August 14, 2015
												The PC version of this game is horrible.  First off, the port was a complete disaster.  The tutorial and on-screen hints are all based on controller schemes.  I.E.  Screen will tell you to press the "A" button to open a door, and the same button to enter a garage with your car, but in a keyboard, each function is bound to a different key.  So you're standing there pressing every key to figure it out.  "Check the bindings on the settings screen." you say?  Well, good luck there cause it doesn't tell you anything there.Second, the texture resolution seem stuck on low, and you have to do some googling/hacking to get a slight improvement, which still looks like garbage.Finally, and the worst crime of all, there is barely ANY content in this game.  It's barely longer than a playable demo.  There are only 2 main towns, and about 10 side quests, and maybe 15 or so main quests.  The expansion DLC's are both just mediocre.  And one of the extra weapons you get is not bound to a number by default!Not worth the money, even when it on sale for like $6.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 22, 2014
												A truly underrated gem.RAGE is a visceral first-person shooter with vehicular combat.Many mistake the game for an open world-type; RPG. It does implement RPG elements in the vehicle and gun categories - allowing you to upgrade and customize your guns and vehicle the way you want to play. Each unique gun has multiple types of ammunition to kill mutants with, and the vehicle comes with many different options such as turrets, mines and rocket launchers. The game is somewhat "open world", but in a linear fashion - i.e., there are only so many places you can go and the canyons between factions usually provide more of a driving segment than a trek on foot. That being said it is still a big game with plenty to explore and take in. The Wasteland is home to many factions, such as: RESISTANCE - A group of people who seek to destroy the Authority's power over the Wasteland.AUTHORITY- A highly organized and weaponized military force that controls and shapes the Wasteland how they see fit. Unlike the mutants and bandits that wander the Wasteland, the Authority knows what it's doing. They use personal energy shields, recharging stations that refill their energy meters, and utilize cover and tactics.BANDITSGearheads - They are the strongest, most intelligent bandit clan in the whole Wasteland, and are best at using heavy machinery and producing energy. They are heavily armored and have the second strongest Minigun soldier. Their combat preference centers around explosives and robotics, making extensive use of Sentry Bots and Turrets.Ghosts - An insane group of cannibals whose dwellings and vehicles are littered with decorative skulls and blood smears as signs of their victories in the Wasteland. They are very agile, maneuvering around the environment with ease performing jumps and other tricks to disorient enemies. They prefer close-in, hand-to-hand combat, making use of Wingsticks and bladed weapons like sickles and kitchen knives. They also sometimes use pistols and assault rifles.Jackal Clan - They're the second most powerful clan, bested only by the Gearheads in manpower. Being agile and tenacious of life, they wear minimal armor and are armed mainly with improvised hand weapons and crossbows. They also use a unique explosive called the Balloon Bomb. They howl and yip, using the the canyon walls to amplify the echos of their shouts and make intruders think that there are more of them in any one spot than there really are. They surprise and swarm their foes, rushing in groups of up to six at a time.Scorchers -  Much like the Ghosts in the way they use environment to their advantage, but they aren't cannibals. They use improvised hand weapons, including spiked baseball bats, as well as firearms and grenades. They worship the Apophis asteroid as a God and decorate themselves, their vehicles and their residences with images of fire and destruction. They're masters of ambush, hunting in packs and surprising their victims in the most unlikely places.Shrouded Clan - They are the most technologically advanced and intelligent Bandit Clan in the Northern Wasteland, and also strong enemies. They tend to use assault rifles and grenades, and use cover frequently.Wasted Clan - A group of British-accented bandits with gung-ho mentality, which means they will suicidally charge at you. They prefer hand weapons, explosives, firearms and are particularly adept at vehicular combat.9/10 Highly Recommended.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 3, 2014
												(RAGE: Wasteland Legends multiplayer mode will have a review soon!)PROS: - Amazing gunplay - Vehicle gameplay is full of control - Extra goodies, minigames, and easter eggs - Exploration is key for a good time - Side missions are so enjoyableCONS:(None of these take away from the game itself, they just get annoying) - AMD Driver issues - FOV is way too lowOVERVIEW:     RAGE is an amazing experience, one that will be remembered in my heart for a long time. I originally played through RAGE on the Xbox 360, but during that playthrough, I only went through the game in a linear fashion. For my second playthrough on the PC, I thought i'd explore the content some more. RAGE starts off with you waking up in an Ark. "Welcome to the future!", the game tells you as you come to realize that the future looks terrible. Turns out, an asteroid had collided with Earth, wiping out nearly every city, or at least all the cities around you. People are still around, but they are from the future, as you are considered to be from the past. RAGE emphazises popularity and community, and with all the enjoyable characters, amazing voice acting and sound design and art design, the game can grab you easily and fit you in with the world to help you understand all the struggles these people are going through. Every character is unique and equally lovable. The world is huge and fun to explore. Tons of side missions can be optionally accepted, which can also lead to new areas you would have never explored before. 4 well hidden easter eggs which are, not only rewarding, but very reminisant (Once you find them, you'll know what i'm talking about). Tons of collectable cards around the entire game which can be used to make some extra cash by playing a game of cards in town, which is actually really fun, despite how simple the game itself looks. The gunplay in RAGE is amazing. There is not a complete plethora of weapons, and I do wish there were more, but what's given to you is great in its own entirety. Upgrades can be purchased and found in side missions as rewards which is a great way to encourage these missions, because the upgrades from side missions, like the auto-sniper upgrade, are really really useful. Every single area you explore is insanely fleshed out and impressive at the same time, thanks to id Tech5, showing off amazing visuals with strong gameplay. One they you may notice about RAGE is how difficulty balances with your items. It's weird, but it works. I played through the game on Normal, which, later in the game, does get pretty difficult. Enemies become a lot tougher. This is where id's genious balancing comes into play. You have 10 bandages and you're fighting against heavily armored bandits. Yes, as you keep getting low on health, you can just hit Q to quickly heal, but as long as you keep getting shot and low on health, you'll quickly use up your bandages, meaning you have to use other things to kill your enemies quickly so they dont deplete your bandages. What goes along with great gunplay? Your choices of ammunition. This is where RAGE becomes so much more fun, trying to play with the different ammo types, seeing what each one does, ranging from Electric Darts to Dynamite Darts to Mind Control Darts, all holding their own unique ability. The mind control darts allow you to take over an enemy and guide them and blow them up, killing them and damagin enemies around them. Electric darts allow you to shock enemies, of course, but also can hit water to shock anyone touching the water. It's all basic stuff, but makes RAGE so much more enjoyable. In RAGE, there is a lot of driving and a lot of combat while driving. New cars can be unlocked in races, which are extremely fun thanks to how much control driving actually has. After winning Race Certificates, you can buy upgrades for your car such as armor or themes. Different cars have different gun limitations, such as the Anarchy Edition Rat Rod, only being able to have one type of gun at a time, while cars like the Monarch allow for all types of weapons on the car at the same time. Bandits in cars can also be killed for extra cash in both sides of the Wasteland. Overall, i'm impressed with how much content is actually in RAGE.     RAGE is a great game, amazing at best. It does very little to upset me besides the occasional FPS drops and the annoying FOV, but those don't take away from the game's atmoshpere and gameplay. I recommend RAGE to everyone. It's fun, interesting, and a game that encourages all types of play rather than a few, which is done well in every way.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 29, 2014
												Deeply disappointed. I had been very excited about a new game from ID. It was Doom that had dragged me into the video game world (and ruined my university days) and another game that could distract me from how much my life sucked seemed impossible to say no to. Well, except that I was broke...because my life sucked. Then I found it on sale and had to have it! And I opened it knowing I would love it. Except I didn't. The first thing I ran into was how unappealing  NPC characters were  (though Goodman wasn't TOO bad), or even outright creapy (but not in the good way, but in the "hide your children way"). The interaction with the the NPCs is very limited and two-dimentional. Although it does have  the benifit of limiting the amount of time you have to spend with the creapy ones... There was a little eye candy (Marry me, Jani!), but not like you are getting personal time with them.The bad guys are also disappointing. I swear, one of the groups (the guys with the remote control exploding toy cars) was a perfect rip off of the bad guys from game Fear. The exact dialog and voices. I can only hope it was done ironically. The other bad guy groups are neary as bed. One group sounds the they are auditioning for the Grumpy Bears (Care Bear's mortal enemies), and one group sounds like "bad russian stereotype". The battle models are nice but still predictable, fine, but it is difficult to take seriously when your killing what sounds like an ogre that was eaten by a teddy bear, or that cartoon Boris character. You want to have faith in the fantasy, but you just can't.The guns are not bad, but "select one of 4" for a quick scroll through is stupid. Actually most of the "self" interface is a disaster. And where the hell is the health bar??? If you see "red" you are almost dead? Was that the plan?? Granted scrounging for health packs is so 1992 (when I was failing university), but it did give some purpose to all the wandering around. Hide and you heal? Right...nanites. Just don't get shot with something too big or too often. Granted, the whole thing did work for Call of Duty pretty good so maybe I shouldn't judge that one.Next, the cars are a pain is the♥♥♥♥♥to drive, and the game leans heavily on their use. Not only do you need to use them for transportation to missions across the waste lands (fair enough) and engage in combat on the way their (rip off Mad Max much, but that is alright too), but the game forces you to constantly upgrade your car by doing these frustrating off-story racing missions. The vehicle controls are so bad that instead of hours of fun, it was hours of screaming (literally) frustration. My carpal tunnel stress made my teen years look like a knitting class. In terms of game benefit, there is none; in no way does it push the story along. And the race tracks are the same space as the road warrior-ing. You could say irony, but to me it says the producers were to lazy/cheap to program more space, or to add more to the story. Driving itself is the complaint, or my skill at it; I had just finished Borderlands 2 and Far Cry 2, and there is HJGE driving in both, but those two games didn't have me on the edge of rage-quit (no pun intended) every time I got behind the wheel. The most frustrating thing was the narrow path that the levels follow. The driving sucked but the play space is extremely limited. With the current focus in gaming being giant sandbox worlds, not being able to climb a rock thats knee high, or jump a waist high railing seems kinda silly. Far Cry 2 has you wandering all over the place, looking for new angles on a problem or for monetary resources. Borderlands 2 does the same (A). The Rage developers create a rather nice (or nasty) world that you want to go look at up close, but they keep you locked on a tight path leading from A to B, and thats it. And there were some REALLY cool scenery, with the classic ID giant biomass...gunk...whatever the hell that was about. They never explained it but it was attention grabbing.And how many games can you rip off at one time? Fallout? With Arks and post-apocolyptic cities and mutants and waste land bandits and picking up trash to sell to buy bullets? And an empty bottle is worth money but no one has stripped the vending machines for parts or food preservation systems? And no one has thought to take the pre-disaster money out of it yet either? Oh, right, its a video game and internal consistancy is optional. What other games was there...Oh yeah, all that spreading alien biomass, line Doom. Well it is ID software so, why not. And Bethesda so sure, nobody to claim copyright infringement. But the lack of originality is a disappointment for the people playing. When you go "hey, its just like Fallout", that should be an indication that you are lacking in creativity. And the voices from Fear? This doesn't inspire...I will give the credit for the conspiracy with Apophis though. Not original, but at least its timely.In all, I would NOT recommend this game to anyone. Panic firefights, yes, but too much unnecessary frustration and mood  breaking faults. I give it a >D< for Disappointing. And I bought it on sale!I will say thanks for the Shotgun. I can never have enough shotgun...And also for Jani, Friday and Destinee...but don't tell my girlfriend.0)

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												RAGE is a shooter set in a post-apocalyptic future. RAGE is strictly a shooter (with no RPG mechanics like you'd find in the newer Fallouts), and its world is far less believable - more Mad Max than plausible future prediction. I must say that the story is linear and boring, but in the light of the previous sentence, criticising it would just seem petty.Let's get the good over with first. RAGE looks fantastic: the graphics and the overall design are very good indeed. Character models are great and the gestures natural-looking, although most of the characters have little to say. The shooting is better than I am used to as well, with dead enemies tumbling over obstacles and maintaining momentum instead of just slumping over or ragdollizing ridiculously. Most factions have some lore tacked onto them, and the enemies fight accordingly: some gangs prefer to take cover behind each other, others like to use explosives, while others might prefer to close in without too much organizing.That's about it for the good stuff, unfortunately. So here comes the flak:1) The weapons are poorly balanced. The assault rifle and machine gun are particularly useless against regular enemies, and I noticed almost exclusively favouring the shotgun and wingstick (bladed boomerang). Most weapons have different ammunition to choose from; this can transform the regular pistol into a powerful magnum, the shotgun into a grenade launcher, the crossbow into a kind of long-distance taser. While this makes otherwise poor weapons at least feasible, it also moves the good ones further ahead of the game.2) The world is tiny. It attempts to give an impression of a biggish sandbox, but there are only two hub towns and there's fairly little to do outside of missions (which are few as well). Exploration is basically useless. If you're here for a Fallout 3/New Vegas experience, forget it.3) Remember those great graphics I mentioned? Well guess what, there is a problem: texture pop-in is a major issue without unofficial fixes (which are easy to find on the Internet, thank Christ). Even with powerful hardware, you can turn 180 degrees and have to wait a second or two to wait for the textures to load, then turn back and have to wait for the game to load the same textures you were looking at not five seconds earlier.4) There are maybe two boss fights, both of them boring, and neither of them at the end of the game, so the rocket launcher and BFG are pretty much useless unless you go for some über-difficult playthrough. Makes me wonder why they bothered with said weapons in the first place.5) You may have guessed this already, but the ending is crap. You just throw wingsticks for fifteen minutes and get confetti dropped on you with a "you win" cutscene on the background (metaphorically, of course). There is no build-up to a grand end, the game just sort of stops short and goes "fine, you've won."Probably the most mediocre game that I have ever played, if that makes any sense.

Posted: July 1, 2016
												In my opinion, Rage isn't so bad, for the price at least ($4.99 Discount) ($9.99 Original price). The game suffers greatly from pop-ins, boring story, and stiff gameplay. For some reason lowering the graphic settings seems to help simmer down the pop in issues for me. The FPS combat aspect is fun but still lacking. The enemies' movements are pretty cool, but you as the player, your movements are very poor in comparison.If the player had the abilities to evade and maneuver more like or similar to the enemies it would be a great asset to the gameplay. I haven't gotten far into the story, but I can tell you now it isn't something great. While the beginning shows something unique it quickly starts to fall bland and boneless. So far it has been missions such as:"Go to this person and get something."OH, that person's something has been stolen. "Go to a Raider's camp and retrieve it."There is no actual Open world, everything is oddly convenient. Also, you can't pick up enemy weapons and gear. The game is very, very, basic. Which is unfortunate, it had potential. Rage has a Mad Max feel to it, you can race with your buggy and combat enemies with mounted weapons, but sadly the world just isn't open enough to justify it. This game is simply nothing exciting, but truth is I'm enjoying the game for what it costs. I would say give the game a try if it's on discount. I wouldn't recommend paying $10 as for this game honestly doesn't feel like a $10 game.Final Rating: 6/10 Could've been much better.

content:
Posted: June 7, 2015
												RAGE is a game that fails to live up to any of its potential. If you go in expecting Fallout you will be sorely disappointed, since it's a linear shooter with (bad) vehicle sequences in a hub world. The weapon variety is excellent, but there's really no reason to use much more than the handgun. Enemies take twice as long to kill as they should, and their AI isn't nearly good enough to make an extended firefight against 3 guys interesting. There's no real challenge, since if you know how to circle strafe you can beat most enemies with just your fists. The story is as forgettable as it gets, and the ending is the biggest anticlimax I've ever experienced in the game. The biggest offense this game commits is that it is dreadfully boring. I had to force myself to actually finish it, as all of the combat was boring as hell, the level design is muddy brown and blurry thanks to an obnoxious film grain effect that can't be turned off. Don't buy this game.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 21, 2014
												Where to begin… So as stated on the box art: RAGE, from the creators of doom and quake. This would seem promising considering this game comes from the creators of two of the best series of all time, but does it really? The answer is no… RAGE falls way short of even being somewhat decent. Here are the reasons I found RAGE to be a complete disappointment and the only rage that came from this experience is the rage that I now have towards id software. Shame because id software was my favorite developer.And just a fyi, my pc is perfectly compatible to play anything you throw at it, Tomb Raider, Bioshock Infinite, Dishonored, Shadow Warrior (2013) and Sniper Elite: Nazi Zombie Army 2 all work on the highest settings without a problem.First of all, the graphics… I’m sure we all have heard the nightmare about the graphics being terrible, but let me be more specific. Long story short, the game wasn’t programmed correctly. For example, when I look at something, it will take a few seconds before the textures load in, then I’ll look somewhere else and those textures do the same thing, then I look back at the first place and those textures have to load BACK in. Please explain the logic in this game, the textures are not supposed to vanish when you look away, they’re supposed to stay there until you are far away or have loaded another map. Aside from this, the textures are a very low quality/low resolution. So even after the textures are loaded 5 seconds after you look at them, they still look ugly anyway. I have seen various solutions to fix all of this, and none of them have worked; although the game should be programmed correctly so you don’t even have to waste your time on this. Is it really too much to ask for? All we want is a game that we can load up and be ready to play, we don’t want to spent 2 hours trying various solutions just to get the stupid game to work. Then to top all this off, considering there so many problems with textures popping in, we are also given the worst problem of all… lag. As I said before, my pc has more than enough power to run this game. I can play Bioshock Infinite and Tomb Raider on the highest settings with no problem, but I can’t play RAGE (a game that’s 2 years older) on even the lowest settings. So good job id software, I’m sure you’re very proud of yourselves; you successfully created a game that is nearly unplayable. So aside from the game looking like something you found in the back of the refrigerator from 3 months ago, and the game running like a truck with cement tires…. that are shaped like squares, maybe the actually game play will be fun?…… Who am I kidding, they can’t even get the game to run properly, why on earth would the actual game be fun? I will admit, the first 2 hours were certainly fun, brought back memories of the classic id software games, just with horrible graphics. But then after the 2 hours of the fun shooting/exploring/collecting, it decides to take a rather stupid turn in events. First of all, the entire aspect of driving just literally killed the game. I didn’t come here to drive a buggy that explodes every 5 min and am forced to upgrade and waste all the money I just spent 4 hours collecting. If id software wanted to make a driving game, then they should of made a driving game. There is a reason we have different genre’s of games, not so that we can take each genre and awkwardly merge them together that does nothing but fills you with rage *cough cough* So aside from the stupid driving/vehicle upgrade monstrosity, ok lets go shoot things! “NO TO HELL WITH THAT” says id software, “HOW ABOUT YOU GO DELIVER MAIL INSDEAD!” yes this is correct, after 3 hours, the shooting completely stops and you find yourself delivering mail and doing other completely stupid/boring/uneventful tasks. After many hours I had absolutely no use for my weapons and the game didn’t even let me carry them (I guess they disappeared to Narnia) Long story short; the game play sucks, it’s probably better to just replay the first 2 hours a few times then go buy another game.So what’s left? Oh, yes, the story….. *falls on the ground laughing* yea there’s absolutely no reason to even talk about that.So taking everything into consideration, we have a game that wasn’t programmed correctly, stupid graphics, stupid game play, horrible merging of two completely different genre’s and little to no story. 1/10

There are almost zero customization in the game except for fixed weapons and vehicles upgrades and ammo types. Do take note that this is a ported game from console and its really buggy with choppy graphics specially when running on ATI graphics card. There are some alternatives out there but it won't resolve the issue completely. If you are looking for the Anarchy Edition, try third party legitimate website for the DLC pack.

												An ideal game for someone like me. Non linear in most places, linear in some, story driven, GREAT characters, even greater animations, solid gameplay + good focus on combat.The game is immense. It really plays as good as it looks and that's rare in most games. The levels are vast and detailed and the weapons and gadgets are loads of fun to upgrade and play around with. There's a good mix of linear and non linear gameplay which means that there's an equal amount of attention to the story and the rpg aspect (rpg's usually have a not so deep story).Although it's post apocalyptic, it's seriously original and the detailed environments and genuine atmosphere prove this. I cannnot believe only 7 people on my friends list have this game! :D9/10 (because no game can be completely perfect ^_^)

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 23, 2014
												The Short: An unsuccessful blend of genresThe Long:With a setting very much like Fallout 3, RAGE instead focuses on being a straight 3D Shooter (not surprisingly given that it’s an id-game) and throws in some fancy driving/racing for good measure. But all these elements never quite gel. The driving feels very much like an afterthought to amp up the game (or an attempt to channel Mad Max 2) but not only does this feel like a separate game within the game (which the racing basically is) but it very much sabotages any kind of open world feeling games like Fallout 3 offer, since you don’t explore the world, you simply drive through it … fast!Also the pacing of the campaign is terrible. It’s basically the concept of a linear shooter disguised as a RPG quest system. The player is rushed from one mission to the next. There are few side quests, mostly lazily designed by revisiting a previous location playing it backwards from end to start the second time. RPG elements are rudimentary and never quite pay off.Characters are superficial and you never get emotionally invested in their stories or fates. But at least the voice acting is fairly good.The storyline is badly constructed. Starting from the initial point from the player being rescued by Hagar just to be send out again to do missions, over establishing the faceless Authority (which way too  much looked like Half-Life 2’s Combine troops) as villains before even properly explaining what makes them villainous, to shoving the player towards joining a Resistance he knows little about. As in fact the whole background of this world is never properly established.On the bright side the game looks very good and plays quite well as a shooter. The locations are well designed, with a decent amount of attention to detail.In my opinion the game would have been better had it focused on being a 3D Shooter. Driving could still have been part of the game, but in a way harmonious to the gameplay (e.g. like Far Cry 2 - as mediocre as that game was).The way it is RAGE pretends to be more than it is and fails on living up to that pretense. It’s not a bad game, but playing it leaves one disappointed because it promised more than it delivered. The ending is also fairly unsatisfactory, but I assume the developers pretty much envisioned it with some "RAGE 2" in mind. In a better game it would have disappointed me. Here I really didn't care.

Posted: October 11, 2011
												I'm tossed on this game. Everything about me wants to love this new shooter from the gods that damn near invented the fps genre. However, it appears IDs design team thought it would be best to stick with game play from the 1990's. Rage looks great, no doubt. The enviroments look amazing for a post apocalyptic game. Combat is fierce and all the weapons sound and feel great. So whats wrong you ask? Everything else! ID isnt know for storytelling, but after 10+ years of creating games, you would think their narrative abilities would have improved over the years. It feels like they just made a moderate sized world full of things to gib and tacked on some ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t story a 5th grader wrote. Vehicles feel more like a afterthought. The fact that its you main mode of transportation really hurts too. In a nutshell, if you like mindless, boring shooting elements with a halfed♥♥♥♥♥crafting system and a lame♥♥♥♥♥travel system. Then you will like this over priced, over rated, over hyped release.

number of helpful: 14 of 28 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 10, 2013
												To put it bluntly Rage is dumb.I sorta got behind the idea of Rage, being a post apocalyptic Mad-Max style game. The only problem is that Borderlands and Fallout 3 did it first. Indeed while playing Rage it feels just like playing Borderlands without cel shaded graphics and the humor.The lack of humor is what startled me with Rage. All the character are stock action movie grizzled veterans, the plot is extremely generic, almost everything about it is treated like the characters are incapable of laughing at their ridiculous situation. There are good things about it, I mean the gunplay is alright and the maps are spectacularly detailed. But all the maps are tediously linear and while there are reasons to backtrack through them, you wouldn't want to. That's not even mentioning the technical problems with the game's engine, many of which still exist and have yet to be patched outI question why this game was made and why Id would stoop so low to just make a more generic Borderlands with Call of Duty elements. One that feels like nobody put any time or attention into detail and just surgically inserted elements because they thought it would sell better.

content:
Posted: September 15, 2012
												A disappointing clone of Borderlands, Rage really has nothing to recommend it at all. It smacks terribly of a brilliantly designed engine in desperate need of a game to make the most of it. It completely lacks artistic flair, unlike Borderlands, which has oodles. The game just doesn't have any character at all. Did you ever watch the series Tru Calling? Well the game-play strongly reminds me of that series. You would have to watch the series to know why. And if I sound harsh, well, yes I am, but I expected much better from the company that pretty much invented the FPS game genre.Recommended? No, I am afraid not. I guess when it's in the sales, then OK, but in the mean time buy Borderlands instead.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 4, 2016
												Lackluster and anticlimatic are about the right words that can be used to sum up this game.The combat is decent. It's nothing awe inspiring, but it holds its own. The AI seems a little smarter than the norm, as it will allow squads of enemies to work as teams to advance, retreat, or attempt to outflank the player. It has its holes that can be exploited and sometimes does some dumb things, but for the most part provided for satisfying combat.Car combat can be a little frustrating due to clunky controls. It also seems to serve no point other than a novelty or to disguise the game world to seem more open and exansive. It is mostly a boring affair that wouldn't have been missed if it was not in the game.There is an illusion of an open world, but the game areas are actually quite linear. There are many side missions that seem pointless and unrewarding. It probably didn't help that rewards were mysterious and the game is not very forthcoming in communicating what they were. They also tell little about the world you are in. Very thin and bland and could easily be avoided, in favor of sticking with the main mission, without much loss to the experience whatsoever. The game world itself felt rather shallow and it was difficult to relate to or care about anyone or anything within it.Lastly, and probably my biggest gripe, the game just seems to abruptly end in a very anticlimatic fashion. There really wasn't any real main antigonist in the game. You hear rumors and details of the promise of some kind of rival that the player may have to face, but none of it ever comes to fruition. There is never even a single encounter, dialogue, or anything with a supposed main antagonist. The ending of the game lacks any kind of boss encounter at all, even though it leads the player to believe that one should be expected. It's as if the developers ran out of time and resources to flesh out anything the game teases the player with and just abruptly ends. Very lackluster and disappointing, nearly feeling like a waste of time.Only get it if you have a serious hankering for a single player FPS and you've played everything better already. Only get it on sale as well. Or better yet, save your time and play something better.

As in fact the whole background of this world is never properly established.On the bright side the game looks very good and plays quite well as a shooter. The locations are well designed, with a decent amount of attention to detail.In my opinion the game would have been better had it focused on being a 3D Shooter. Driving could still have been part of the game, but in a way harmonious to the gameplay (e.g. like Far Cry 2 - as mediocre as that game was).The way it is RAGE pretends to be more than it is and fails on living up to that pretense. It’s not a bad game, but playing it leaves one disappointed because it promised more than it delivered. The ending is also fairly unsatisfactory, but I assume the developers pretty much envisioned it with some "RAGE 2" in mind. In a better game it would have disappointed me. Here I really didn't care.

I guess when it's in the sales, then OK, but in the mean time buy Borderlands instead.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 21, 2014
												Where to begin… So as stated on the box art: RAGE, from the creators of doom and quake. This would seem promising considering this game comes from the creators of two of the best series of all time, but does it really? The answer is no… RAGE falls way short of even being somewhat decent. Here are the reasons I found RAGE to be a complete disappointment and the only rage that came from this experience is the rage that I now have towards id software. Shame because id software was my favorite developer.And just a fyi, my pc is perfectly compatible to play anything you throw at it, Tomb Raider, Bioshock Infinite, Dishonored, Shadow Warrior (2013) and Sniper Elite: Nazi Zombie Army 2 all work on the highest settings without a problem.First of all, the graphics… I’m sure we all have heard the nightmare about the graphics being terrible, but let me be more specific. Long story short, the game wasn’t programmed correctly. For example, when I look at something, it will take a few seconds before the textures load in, then I’ll look somewhere else and those textures do the same thing, then I look back at the first place and those textures have to load BACK in. Please explain the logic in this game, the textures are not supposed to vanish when you look away, they’re supposed to stay there until you are far away or have loaded another map. Aside from this, the textures are a very low quality/low resolution. So even after the textures are loaded 5 seconds after you look at them, they still look ugly anyway. I have seen various solutions to fix all of this, and none of them have worked; although the game should be programmed correctly so you don’t even have to waste your time on this. Is it really too much to ask for? All we want is a game that we can load up and be ready to play, we don’t want to spent 2 hours trying various solutions just to get the stupid game to work. Then to top all this off, considering there so many problems with textures popping in, we are also given the worst problem of all… lag. As I said before, my pc has more than enough power to run this game. I can play Bioshock Infinite and Tomb Raider on the highest settings with no problem, but I can’t play RAGE (a game that’s 2 years older) on even the lowest settings. So good job id software, I’m sure you’re very proud of yourselves; you successfully created a game that is nearly unplayable. So aside from the game looking like something you found in the back of the refrigerator from 3 months ago, and the game running like a truck with cement tires…. that are shaped like squares, maybe the actually game play will be fun?…… Who am I kidding, they can’t even get the game to run properly, why on earth would the actual game be fun? I will admit, the first 2 hours were certainly fun, brought back memories of the classic id software games, just with horrible graphics. But then after the 2 hours of the fun shooting/exploring/collecting, it decides to take a rather stupid turn in events. First of all, the entire aspect of driving just literally killed the game. I didn’t come here to drive a buggy that explodes every 5 min and am forced to upgrade and waste all the money I just spent 4 hours collecting. If id software wanted to make a driving game, then they should of made a driving game. There is a reason we have different genre’s of games, not so that we can take each genre and awkwardly merge them together that does nothing but fills you with rage *cough cough* So aside from the stupid driving/vehicle upgrade monstrosity, ok lets go shoot things! “NO TO HELL WITH THAT” says id software, “HOW ABOUT YOU GO DELIVER MAIL INSDEAD!” yes this is correct, after 3 hours, the shooting completely stops and you find yourself delivering mail and doing other completely stupid/boring/uneventful tasks. After many hours I had absolutely no use for my weapons and the game didn’t even let me carry them (I guess they disappeared to Narnia) Long story short; the game play sucks, it’s probably better to just replay the first 2 hours a few times then go buy another game.So what’s left? Oh, yes, the story….. *falls on the ground laughing* yea there’s absolutely no reason to even talk about that.So taking everything into consideration, we have a game that wasn’t programmed correctly, stupid graphics, stupid game play, horrible merging of two completely different genre’s and little to no story. 1/10

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2015
												You know what gets under my skin, no one seems to know what this game is, or more specifically how good it is. In case you were wondering this game is AMAZING and doesn't deserve the ghostly existence it has, even after all of this time. Let me go over a list of the pros and cons.PROS- Variety of gameplay (with tons of weapons and custimizations there is a variety of ways to take out your target (ex. the crossbow can allow one hit kills from a distance like a sniper rifle, can mind control an enemy so that he suicide bombs the other enemies behind cover, and can EXPLODE to do extra damage to enemies with heavy armor and such. However this is if you have the ammo for it))- Brightly colored cast of characters (and trust me there are ALOT)- Bullet realism ( every shot counts and you can tell when you land a hit)- Overall enjoyment and entertainment (and really whats better than that)CONS- There isn't a solid storyline and it can get confusing at time to time- The game is designed for consoles and you can tell especially when it comes to switching weapons which can be a major pain at times- Some aspects with the graphics (random trees and some other objects just spawn in with the ugliest sprites at times.)The cons aren't THAT big of an issue and using a controller is almost a necessity when dealing with the switching weapons which can be a bit crippling when your switching ammo types to match the enemy your facing and the mouse just takes too long to find and drag and etc. But I digress. This game is a most have for those who seek a bit of a challenge (and I don't mean with the pc controls) with a brightly colored cast and a variety of ways to play. Ignore what anyone has told you, this game is GOOD.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 5, 2012
												Another fantastic game from id with awkward graphics. The main campaign will take you about 10 hours between two hub cities filled with side activities to do, like playing a CCG, "wanted board" quests, gambling, and car racing. In fact about half of the game takes place in your vehicle of choice; whether you are traveling to the next mission objective, farming upgrade tickets, or just hunting for sewer entrances (hidden DLC missions that comes free), there is a lot of non-FPS stuff to do. The main problems with this game are engine issues. There is a lot of texture popup without .cfg tweaks and a lot of the environmental objects (tables, radios, books, etc.) look like they have a single texture on them. It's a bit jarring when characters have real fluid, complex animations and top-notch texture and model work but they are surrounded by untextured objects. If you can deal with the uneven graphics, this is a real solid (albeit too easy) game.

Lack of challenged boss fight and unlike DOOM 3, most of maps are blocked by invisible walls which it's really non-sense in free-roam concept.

												TL;DR:In all honesty, the game is perfectly competent in what it does. In terms of presentation, it was consistently at 60 frames a second with only a few performance issues. It’s just a game that comes across as boring and heartless. It felt like there were a series of extra check boxes that were added to their list of necessities in development to try and appease various niches when they should have focused on making a good/creative shooter without all these flat bells and whistles that take away from the core experience. As a result, instead of standing out from the crowd Rage manages to look more bland than its competitors.For the full review, go here: http://dagondogs.com/2015/02/17/rage-review/

												Surely being a fan of ID Software, I had to try out their new game RAGE.Thinking it could be as fun as Doom or Quake, but I was wrong, this wasn't a game for me.There's nothing to complain about the graphics, using the "MEGA TEXTURE" technology it sure looks prettyBut I didn't like the gameplay, and I didn't like the "Mad Max" setting with the combined FPS and driving.Last time playing RAGE was back in 2012, and I thought that maybe I should give it another chance, but about half an hour in, I recognized it hadn't changed for me, so I gave up and quit.Now, writing this I've played the new Doom (2016) and that's more like it, much more up my street.If you are like me, prefering the old Doom and Quake, I will not recommend RAGEbut if you like the "Mad Max" style combined with FPS elements....you should give it a go.
