number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 29, 2016
												Seriously... BORING UNEVENTFUL STORY.I actively wished the entire game to have a CHOICE in ANYTHING, especially being able to side with the so-called 'authority' because they got cool armor and seemed to have some sembelance of an idea what the hell they were doing.I do not recommend this game for someone who wants:1) A good storyline with a thorough ending.2) Interesting characters you can interact with3) An open worldAdditionally, if you DO NOT want the following; beware:1) Racing is REQUIRED in the main storyline. (I do okay in racing games and was able to complete them, but I do not like them)2) a couple mini bosses but no real skill requirement to fight anything3) Endless random vendor trash to sell for no apparent reason.4) Endless ammo if you so choose.5) Enemies which while having some intelligence, still seem to put their back to you when you throw a grenade at them. (seriously, just watched 2 people run around cover and turn to face the grenade with me looking at them... smart.)6) A lack of 'fun guns' to play with. Ultimately, I ended up using the shotgun almost the entire game because using 'Pop Rockets' (grenade ammo) is simply the only weapon I found enjoyable, side for shooting mutants with an assault rifle and then slamming them in the face with melee. (other than this, wingsticks were my only other weapon choice)-Some BACKGROUND:I played RAGE originally back in 2012 and after getting bored with it, I stopped playing. This was after about 2 hours of the game and I had not completed the game.Then, again in 2014 I picked up the game again (figuratively) and played past the part I stopped at previously. Again, I became bored out of my mind and uninstalled it.Finally, in 2016 I finished it.Yes, I was bored with an id game. Three times now. I only beat the game to prove I could and... dear god it was still a waste of my time. (Surprisingly, yes I always enjoyed Doom 1,2 and 3, also played the original wolfenstein games and commander keen. So, I love id and I think they have a great staff.)Sadly, this game has dissappointed me greatly. When I first picked it up, read the cover and thought back to the trailers; I said "My, this would rock if it's anything like what is described." That is simply not the case.I was hopeful of a Fallout3/NewVegas with a doom atmosphere, because out of everything I want a survival horror wasteland game if I can get one. (Even if doom is a bit shooty ;-)Regardless, this game at first tries to fool you. It gives you quests, loot drops, corpses to desecrate and thereby steal gear from; but ultimately none of it matters. On top of all this; characters all spew dialog for long enough to make me decide to step away from my desk to grab a snack while they yammer, before I can actually get a quest or shop from them.If you want to jump into a shooter and just blow people and mutants up, it can be fun. I won't deny that. But ultimately, I have stopped playing it two other times because some areas are just so unbelievably boring.A final thought, the higher you crank the difficulty the higher enemy HP is. (very annoying as that is the only noticable difference)

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 13, 2016
												The artistic direction for this game is phenomenal. Everything from the way the weapons feel, to the lighting and town layouts, straight through to the enemies' costumes and level design really set this title apart from most any other game I've ever played. Gameplay is very very similar to Red Faction Guerilla, but better (also in first person except for the vehicle bits). If you enjoy a game that blends modern shooters (regenerating health) with RPG elements (you can construct items that buff you, or act as sentry turrets or companion robots) and old school gunning (but with great enemy AI that actually uses cover and tactics) then this game is for you. TLDR: Post-Apocalyptic FPS goodness. Buy this game, you won't regret it.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 17, 2016
												One of my favorite shooters. I understand the flaws that it's known for - over promised and under delivered "open" world, so-so driving mechanics, and some graphical glitches. My view may be slightly tainted by the fact that I played this game after having actively avoided shooters for a couple years and purchased it a few years after it came out, so I paid very little for it and played it after all of the patches were released. Having said that, I had a blast with this game. The shooting mechanics and "feel" of the guns is one of, if not the best I've every played, and I enjoyed the atmosphere, enemies and NPCs. The story was not great but I wasn't expecting it to be. The single biggest detriment to the fun of the game for me was the backtracking, but it only occurs a few times, mostly in sewer tunnels and other indoor environments. Some people like their games to last 100s of hours, but if you are like me and tend to lose interest in games when they get long in the tooth (Borderlands), then you will still be having fun when this game ends, which is a plus.If you haven't played this and can get it on sale, and you enjoyed the mechanics of Wolfenstein: New Order, I would highly recommend it.

												This is a game, IMHO that gets canned for being what it should be.  It's a mini-mad max.  If you played Mad Max, or think you want to but want to play something similar, this is it.  Awesome fun game, very replayable for me, looks great on PC.  A great game if you want combat where you don't have to memorise the seven sequence master kill moves for each individual boss.Not an overly difficult game, which is why some people can it.Not an overly long game either, which is why some people can it.But definitly solid and worth playing, if you like this kind of thing.A solid 8.5/10 for me.Having now complete the campaign on PC, it's taken me about 20hrs, completing most of the side missions and getting about 50% of the steam achievements on one playthrough.This game is definitely solid value that is exactly what it pretends to be.  So it's not perfectly an open world environment - who cares!!!  So you revisit some locations a couple of times (they're slightly different each time) this doesn't bother me either.The atmosphere is great, the graphics are very good especially considering a console port.If anything, considering the price I'd bump my rating to 9/10.Get it if you like FPS.

content:
Posted: May 29, 2016
												Seriously... BORING UNEVENTFUL STORY.I actively wished the entire game to have a CHOICE in ANYTHING, especially being able to side with the so-called 'authority' because they got cool armor and seemed to have some sembelance of an idea what the hell they were doing.I do not recommend this game for someone who wants:1) A good storyline with a thorough ending.2) Interesting characters you can interact with3) An open worldAdditionally, if you DO NOT want the following; beware:1) Racing is REQUIRED in the main storyline. (I do okay in racing games and was able to complete them, but I do not like them)2) a couple mini bosses but no real skill requirement to fight anything3) Endless random vendor trash to sell for no apparent reason.4) Endless ammo if you so choose.5) Enemies which while having some intelligence, still seem to put their back to you when you throw a grenade at them. (seriously, just watched 2 people run around cover and turn to face the grenade with me looking at them... smart.)6) A lack of 'fun guns' to play with. Ultimately, I ended up using the shotgun almost the entire game because using 'Pop Rockets' (grenade ammo) is simply the only weapon I found enjoyable, side for shooting mutants with an assault rifle and then slamming them in the face with melee. (other than this, wingsticks were my only other weapon choice)-Some BACKGROUND:I played RAGE originally back in 2012 and after getting bored with it, I stopped playing. This was after about 2 hours of the game and I had not completed the game.Then, again in 2014 I picked up the game again (figuratively) and played past the part I stopped at previously. Again, I became bored out of my mind and uninstalled it.Finally, in 2016 I finished it.Yes, I was bored with an id game. Three times now. I only beat the game to prove I could and... dear god it was still a waste of my time. (Surprisingly, yes I always enjoyed Doom 1,2 and 3, also played the original wolfenstein games and commander keen. So, I love id and I think they have a great staff.)Sadly, this game has dissappointed me greatly. When I first picked it up, read the cover and thought back to the trailers; I said "My, this would rock if it's anything like what is described." That is simply not the case.I was hopeful of a Fallout3/NewVegas with a doom atmosphere, because out of everything I want a survival horror wasteland game if I can get one. (Even if doom is a bit shooty ;-)Regardless, this game at first tries to fool you. It gives you quests, loot drops, corpses to desecrate and thereby steal gear from; but ultimately none of it matters. On top of all this; characters all spew dialog for long enough to make me decide to step away from my desk to grab a snack while they yammer, before I can actually get a quest or shop from them.If you want to jump into a shooter and just blow people and mutants up, it can be fun. I won't deny that. But ultimately, I have stopped playing it two other times because some areas are just so unbelievably boring.A final thought, the higher you crank the difficulty the higher enemy HP is. (very annoying as that is the only noticable difference)

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 12, 2016
												RAGE was mostly a boring generic FPS with a cliff hanger ending that disappointed me even more than the game play.While playing this game the only weapon I ever used consistantly was the shotgun. The shotgun pretty much does everything all the other guns wont. once you get ahold of the shotgun upgrade it and spend the rest of your money on ammo and armor and healing items because running up point blank and blasting nearly every bullet sponge enemy will get you almost an instant kill or it'll take 2-3 shots.The game seems at odds with it self it wants to be a realistic FPS but it also wants to be borderlands and mad max at the same time but doesn't have a big enough world or time to set such things up. It's very clear ID or bethesda wanted to do so much more with this game but it was forced out the door in a some what unfinished state which leads to it's awful ending and it's lack of any real world building. I didn't care about anyone I came across or even my own main character because.... HE DOESN'T TALK. Silent main characters can work but they can be so damn boring sometimes and this is one of those boring cases.The enemies are boring bullet sponges that will have you groaning as you fight them rather than cheering for some action before too long. I'm pretty sure ID or bethesda just sat around playing borderlands and said "we can make it more realistic" and I♥♥♥♥♥♥you not there are actually psychos from borderlands in this game. they're called the Jackals and they just spit out a fake cave man mad man language that sounds like the psychos from borderlands.The only truely good thing I can say about this game is that the female NPC's looked very well animated and diverse for the most part. You'll see repeat faces and find many of the NPC's teleporting from one area to another and it'll have you going "huh.. weren't you just down stairs"The voice acting made me go "hey that's John Goodmen, Oh that's Steve Blum" but never surprised me or impressed me with any emotional scenes. These people are just basically mission information dumps and No one sounds like they had fun at all with their roles.about around 78% of the time I didn't know where the hell to go if the town had a person I needed to talk to or a person to take a mission from due to there being no in town map or navagation. The implications of this make me believe this game was originally meant to be linear or mission based and not an open world. There are only 2 town hubs in the game and one is surprisingly more cool but more confusing to navagate than the other.The graphics HOLY♥♥♥♥♥♥What happened to the graphics. Summery: Things look beautiful from a distance when you get close they look like PURE♥♥♥♥♥♥Basically if you walk to close to anything that isn't an NPC you'll see a very ugly and disgusting low res texture that would make you think you were playing an N64 game. I've seen what the ID tech 5 engine can do in the hands of other game developers but apparently ID can't do♥♥♥♥♥♥with their own engine because everything about this game's texture work is ugly.as for the story it's all over the place. it's cleary they didn't have enough time to make ANYTHING happen the way they wanted. the ARK's that all these "amazing" people are barely talked about and are incredibly confusing. you get called an ARK person by everyone but nothing interesting comes from it. after playing this I see where they got Ideas for doom and THANK GOD doom was actually good because if it was like this I'd never trust ID again.needless to say don't buy this game at full price. I recommend it but just barely.

content:
Posted: March 23, 2014
												The Short: An unsuccessful blend of genresThe Long:With a setting very much like Fallout 3, RAGE instead focuses on being a straight 3D Shooter (not surprisingly given that it’s an id-game) and throws in some fancy driving/racing for good measure. But all these elements never quite gel. The driving feels very much like an afterthought to amp up the game (or an attempt to channel Mad Max 2) but not only does this feel like a separate game within the game (which the racing basically is) but it very much sabotages any kind of open world feeling games like Fallout 3 offer, since you don’t explore the world, you simply drive through it … fast!Also the pacing of the campaign is terrible. It’s basically the concept of a linear shooter disguised as a RPG quest system. The player is rushed from one mission to the next. There are few side quests, mostly lazily designed by revisiting a previous location playing it backwards from end to start the second time. RPG elements are rudimentary and never quite pay off.Characters are superficial and you never get emotionally invested in their stories or fates. But at least the voice acting is fairly good.The storyline is badly constructed. Starting from the initial point from the player being rescued by Hagar just to be send out again to do missions, over establishing the faceless Authority (which way too  much looked like Half-Life 2’s Combine troops) as villains before even properly explaining what makes them villainous, to shoving the player towards joining a Resistance he knows little about. As in fact the whole background of this world is never properly established.On the bright side the game looks very good and plays quite well as a shooter. The locations are well designed, with a decent amount of attention to detail.In my opinion the game would have been better had it focused on being a 3D Shooter. Driving could still have been part of the game, but in a way harmonious to the gameplay (e.g. like Far Cry 2 - as mediocre as that game was).The way it is RAGE pretends to be more than it is and fails on living up to that pretense. It’s not a bad game, but playing it leaves one disappointed because it promised more than it delivered. The ending is also fairly unsatisfactory, but I assume the developers pretty much envisioned it with some "RAGE 2" in mind. In a better game it would have disappointed me. Here I really didn't care.

content:
Posted: September 17, 2016
												First, I want to say I think they should of put more resources into the writing staff.  As you can tell from the other reviews, the end is pretty bad.  But it isn't just this.  There are these choppy transitions, as well as events that totally negate actions that your character just fought over.  It makes no sense.Secondly, the main reason why I do not particularly like this game, is the enemy AI.  What gets remotely difficult are the bandits that run at you, but you can pistol shoot them two or three times, and then melee them, and they drop.  The wing blade helps, but let me get to that in a second.  Or, just use a shotgun.  I literally had the BFG gun, and I used it once in the last dungeon.  I pretty much used the shotgun in the very last fight.  The shot gun wrecks face, and a lot of these enemies run into your face.But that's not the only aspect of the AI that's bad.Enemies with a gun, will hide behind cover, and literally stick their head and upper torso out from covery, to just LOOK.  They don't shoot at you, it isn't quick, they literally position themselves there, and look.  So yeah, I'm going to shoot them.  But it's incredibly dumb.  It turns into this waiting game, because they peak out of cover and you just shoot two to three bullets at a time, and you maximize on the amount of ammo saved, and you don't get hit!  You just have to be patient.I didn't like how there was such a strong limit on the race track.  They make a huge deal about decking out your vehicles, but there isn't nearly enough racing credits to be able to do that.  You start decking out one car, and then another comes along, and you start decking that car out.  Which means, you don't have a fully decked out car.  That annoys me.  :)I wish they didn't increase the difficulty of the game by increasing the amount of ammo it takes to kill a guy.  Like, there has to be some other way.  By increasing the amount of ammo you use, it essentially decreases the amount of money that you have because you have to buy ammo for the next "dungeon."  This component, actually makes money worth something in this game.  However, it is there because it takes a stupid amount of bullets to kill someone.The writing and AI were the two main things that really took away from this game.  It was enjoyable, but I felt dissapointed, especially during the last dungeon.  If you are going to get this game, get it cheap.

content:
Posted: November 16, 2016
												Ok...first, the good stuff: I really enjoyed the animation and the gameplay action of RAGE.  I particularly liked the sounds, which gave the weapons exquisite and unique textures - some of the best sounds of any RPG I've played.  Moreover, the opportunity to craft weapons and items is really cool.Now, the bad stuff:TOO EASY:I played Hard and I got through most of the final mission with a Settler pistol and a machine gun.  Granted, I didn't try Nightmare level, but I don't imagine it would be too much more difficult.WORST ASPECTS:RAGE was way too short (which is the main reason I wouldn't recommend this game: I love to be immersed in a large world and narrative, and this game really has neither).It was also quite difficult to find my way around the game at the beginning - I found myself having to hop online several times to find out how to get to certain menus (since even the PC version is tailored to a console interface).Moreover, RAGE is the Dexter of RPGs, with absolutely, undoubtedly the most anticlimactic, lacklustre, disappointing ending of any RPG I've ever played.  It's as if they ran out of budget close to the end and some CEO told them to wrap it up quick!  I know most don't care about this, but the grammar used to describe the missions reads like the bad undergraduate essays I have to mark.  Come on, Bethesda - pick up your game!

content:
Posted: December 7, 2016
												Rage Review.I just beat the game a few minutes ago and my first initial reaction was...was that it? I beat the game and most side quests in about 12 hours and was left feeling like the game ended in act 2 when it should have had at least 4 acts, if that makes any sense. This review contains minor spoilers.  Overall storyline was a 5 out of 10. Definitely a fail. I didn't feel invested to any of the characters or even the faction I was fighting for, the Resistence. Vehicle Combat again a 5 out of 10. It was horrible but it wasn't overly fun.  Very basic driving, and it felt like a mechanic that was added to the game just for a bit of filler. Ground Combat 7 out of 10. The game does  a bit better here. At times the combat turned towards a very Serious Sam type feel as hordes of enemies bear down on you, which I've never been crazy about. The AI of the combat is poor and the only challenging parts of the ground combat was when they put hordes of enemy against you in a very close room, otherwise all other enemies could be fought every easily by simly moving backwards and having the enemies come to you.Weapons 7 out of 10. Very basic weapons. The upgrades for the weapons were nice but not enough of them. The customized ammo was a nice addition but I felt like their could have big a bigger variety instead of just more powerful bullets (essentially). No weapon in particular stuck out as being really cool. They do have a mind control weapon but IMO they messed it up and it's not very fun with limited effectiveness. Quests 6 out of 10. The have a very repetetive feel to it.  Quests didn't endear me towards certain characters. Graphics  6-7 out of 10. When you think of this game, think Borderlands Graphics. Everything looks semi-painted on the screen and while I wouldn't give Borderlands a lower rating I would this game.  Borderlands has a very unique atmosphere, it has some very beatiful landscapes that add a sense of mystery to the game.  Rage for all it's painted landscapes doesn't offer anything really unique. And because effort wasn't put into making this stand out with interesting textures it gets a lower rating.Other thoughts The game is incredibly linear. If you want to explore a new area, you pretty much need to quest to be able to interact with the environment. The game feels very similar to Borderlands without the funny jokes or interesting landscapes. Overall the game felt rushed, linear and very short. Overall I'd rate the game a generous 6 out of 10.

												With CONTROLLER ON for driving, RAGE asks me to HIT ENTER TO START yet every other prompt in the game is Xbox controller centric.  Why? I'm not using a controller during the non driving segments.  ALTTAB to desktop results in the loss of VSYNCH everytime.  Rocket Rally isn't fun and the races and time trials are too easy.   Music is lost when loading from inside the game until I guess the folks at id think I'm worthy.  A myriad of ultra cool quick use items await yet I can only bind them to 4 keys.  The variances in ammo per weapon are amazing yet to cycle ammo in a weapon that holds 4 types I have to cycle through each with full change ammo animations to get to the one I desire.  Car combat is poorly designed, the Car AI stinks and the mounted minigun is worthless due to the superiority of the other mounted weapons.  Textures are trash and id should be embarassed. Usage of RED X's and ! signs in game break immersion.Combat,Guns,Ammo,AI movement and all animations are the best.

content:
Posted: January 27, 2016
General ThoughtsInteresting little FPS.  I did enjoy playing, however there were a few things that drive me a little batty.  There was an interesting story that ended aburptly right when it was getting good.  Once completeled I was left with a feeling of, "That's It?!?"  While the game is visually stunning, it did suffer from some issues like LOD popup constantly.  Thankfully these can be 99% eliminated with custom configs.  All in all I had fun playing the game.  I just wished for a more climatic ending.The Good Solid Shooting Mechanics Quest Driven Storyline Adaptive AI Plenty of Eye Candy Caters to multiple playstyles Plenty of timesink distractions (minigames, racing, gambling to name a few) Rewards explorationThe Bad Story Abruptly Ends Funky graphic issues (mostly fixable with custom configs) Crazy economy.   You'll consistently be dumping your earnings into ammo. Vehicles a bit wonky for keyboard/mouse controls.  Controller recommended.

Posted: June 8, 2015
												I've owned the game for years but other than a couple of half hearted starts where I barely put half an hour into it each time I've never played it, Until last week that is.I've just finished my first playthrough which was on Nightmare difficulty, It took over 30 hours to complete and I managed to get 60% of the achievements (which is good for me). I really enjoyed the game, I had no crashes, no bugs and great performance (60 fps at all times) with everything maxed on a 60hz 1080p monitor with vsr pushing it at 1440p. Visually it looks great tooFrom what I remember this game was never one that got rave reviews and I just don't know why.It's a good looking, enjoyable game and the most important thing is that it is what a game should be. FUN. It's quite an old game now meaning you can often pick it up dirt cheap but even at the current price without a sale deal it is well worth getting. If you haven't ever played Rage and it looks like your thing don't wait no longer. Treat yourself as I'm sure you'll enjoy it.

number of helpful: 4 of 9 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												To put it succinctly, Rage was designed to look good in screen shots.  Graphics engine performance, low-res textures, and confining invisible walls are glaring weak performers.For the graphics engine, id relies on Tech 5 version of their in-house developed engine circa 2011.  It is plainly developed with consoles in mind and not the higher performance standards of today's PCs.  Texture pop-ins are unavoidable even after implementing patches and id-suggested tweaks.  I've never seen pop-ins so bad on a modern game.  Pop-ins are extremely evident when you turn your character and terrain textures appear as extremely low-res for a split second before the engine loads the higher resolution texture.  It's kind of sad that id doesn't have the shiniest, red-hot, smokin'-est game engine.  Especially since they've always been crap for story--the graphics were always the "but at least it looks AMAZING!!" fall back.  Not anymore.I don't understand the prevalent use of extremely low-res textures for items and objects in your immediate viscinity.  It's mind-boggling.  I can't fathom how anyone thinks that was a good idea for a PC release. Now, there are some post-release tweaks you can do to some config files that will load higher resolution textures but it's odd that they make you do that little tweak yourself.Lastly, another unavoidable issue is the "on-rails" feeling of the areas.  Invisible walls are prevalent and obnoxious.  Call it console-itis.  It's a sad artifact of porting from a console.Some high points are the character's facial animations and the models themselves.  They're quite nice and rival any of the better implementations seen in LA Noire or even Borderlands 2.The "crafting" and RPG elements, while not amazing, are strong enough to lend some depth to the game especially for an id story.  I've no real complaints there.All in all, I purchased the game for $5 and that's about what I think the game is worth on the PC.  It's worth a shot at a low price point.

Posted: March 18, 2014
												Technological abortion that is MEGATEXTURES notwithstanding, RAGE is not a bad game.  Unfortunately, as AAA games are wont to do, cramming in every mainstream gameplay gimmick like racing, 'open world,' tacked-on multiplayer, rpg lite elements, etc. end up watering down the shooter aspect and results in something that plays like shallower version of Borderlands.   Had id focused on level design and improved AI this would be a much better game.  The fact that this took six plus years and hundreds of millions of dollars to develop is inexplicable (yet par for the course for AAA).All of that said the setting is atmopsheric, the outdoor visuals are pretty, and you're provided with a variety of guns and gadgets to blow stuff up.  A colossal mismanagement of time and money but still an enjoyable experience.

content:

												My initial impressions of Rage left me with disappointment. As a huge fan of the DOOM franchise, I was expecting the id Tech 5 engine to be the basis for DOOM's next installment. So I saw Rage as the engine's test title. While it impressed me graphically, I felt the many subgames within the game got in the way of the plot. I didn't want to spend my time racing or playing cards. I was here to chew bubble gum and kick♥♥♥♥♥ and I was all out of bubble gum. When I got to the end of the campaign, I felt like there could've been more. Then when DOOM never materialized after two Wolfenstein releases and The Evil Within, I felt unsatisfied even more.After a nearly 5 year hiatus, I'm reinstalling it now to start over and give it a second chance. Now that I have my DOOM keeping me happy, perhaps I'll find more to enjoy in Rage.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 5, 2015
												Frankly, I'd feel really ripped off if I'd gotten this game for more than five bucks during a sale.Narrative-wise, it's got nothing going for it. A standard jacked, non-speaking white guy wakes up after an apocalypse and is really good at shooting stuff. There are the obvious mutants and bandit clans, and an authoritarian regime with all the fancy electronics. There are also rebels, and they take a liking to you (for no obvious reason--your character is as bland as they come) and you wind up being the chosen one they've been waiting for to help take control for the good of the people.As much as I love overthrowing ♥♥♥♥♥♥ governments, the rebel characters are all just as bland as you are, they have absolutely no moral complexity (every character falls into the categories of A: kind of annoyed with the oppressive regime and naively waiting around for a Messiah or B: shooting you in the face screaming gibberish), and the story barely wraps up. It's obvious that the game was counting on a sequel  to pull it together, but all the big reveals are already glaringly obvious and I can't see anyone being engaged enough to buy another one.Gameplay-wise, it's almost a bit better. The FPS elements are pretty solid--there's a nice blend of enemies who shoot from cover, stand out in the open with big guns blazing, and leap at you from crazy angles, so you get to play around with your strategy a bit. But even that gets old by the end, and the painfully average vehicle levels (which feel like they were thrown in as an afterthought) don't do nearly enough to break it up. I managed to play all the way through by making a personal challenge to use nothing but crossbow headshots, but frig was that ending ever /not/ worth the work.Basically, if you like the cutthroat FPS combat in gritty, scenic tunnels, you should get Bioshock instead, and if you like the shooter/racer duality in a wasteland survival setting, you should get a PS2 emulator and Jak III. I suppose that's my beef with this game, for everything kinda good about it (the crossbow and the cute steampunk NPCs are literally it for me), there are a dozen other games that do it much better, and have a much more positive overall experience.Don't needlessly subject yourself to this inanity.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												RAGE.The plus points about this game are overlooked by all the negatives. I bought this game hoping it was an open world, exploration game, sort of like Fallout or Borderlands. I was very mistaken because this game is very much story driven and although initially, you get to explore a bit, but afterwards, it feels very linear. The fact that you can't even open your map(wtf, you can't explore without seeing a map) says a lot about "exploring" the world in the description of the game. The combat is also very..shaky, so to say because, well firstly, you can't reload while running and secondly you hesitate for a second to shoot after aiming. There's a small pause in shooting even though you've aimed. Its very irritating if you're not used to it. Other than that, you don't get a lot of side quests unless you absolutely exhaust dialogue with anyone you can talk to. This might infuriate someone, might not. Combat with cars is very aggressive as you can actually die if you're not careful even if your car is at full health. The plus points would be the graphics & textures and the realism of the game. but that is about it.I also hate the fact that so many doors in so many buildings are just "closed". It completely ruins the feeling of exploring the world. It just puts you on a very linear path of "do this and go here" instead of "don't do this, just explore stuff and come back and do this." You can't do that. I almost feel like this game can be compared to Singularity or Crysis because of the linear quest line and your inability to explore the world. The AI racing bots can be easily beaten in races. They're not even a threat after the first lap if you race well. Also, this game is really huge; around 18GB. All in all, I was highly disappointed from this game because I was expecting SO much more and it failed to give me what I had in mind. That being said, this was my opinion and I know people like this game a lot but I did not like it all.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 6, 2016
												tldr; first, then further reading below:Pros:- Beautiful game. From the graphics to the color choices to the excellent level aesthetics, RAGE has an immersive world to explore.- Plenty of tense, enjoyable moments blasting everything from raging mutants to the coordinated assaults of the authority- Enemy animations are a joy to watch. Enemies jump, duck, roll, climb from the ceiling and react to hits from your weapons in a way no other game does- Mixes up the standard shooter genre with driving sections, a light crafting system and different ammo types for most guns offering various ways to use weaponry in interesting waysCons:- The ending is cut short with a fairly anticlimactic assault sequence- Driving mechanics and AI are not as well fleshed out as could be, almost an afterthought for the way some of it works- Multiplayer feels tacked on with the co-op missions being rehashed levels of the campaign and racing that feels dry and boring- Fairly easy game, even on the ultra nightmare difficulty added by the DLCRating: 4/5RAGE... It's a game that a lot of people like to hate on. Looking at it from a perspective purely focused on game design and implementation, yes RAGE is lacking. There's one thing that most people don't take into account when enjoying games however and that is the perspective from games as art. From that standpoint, ID nails it with RAGE. It's a simply beautiful game that stands the test of time even now and because of that:I LOVE RAGEBy far some of the most fun I've had with the game has been bullet spraying, sniping, shotgunning, wingsticking or otherwise pulverizing enemies and seeing their death and reaction animations. Having enemies duck and dodge at the last second, swing across the ceiling and stumble and roll as they're shot in the shoulder is extremely satisfying to watch. It makes the game much more immersive than most shooters where enemies stand there and then die like robots repeating the same motions over and over.The graphics help with this and to this day RAGE has some of the best looking graphics there is. The textures may not hold up to modern ones but the overall aesthetic and graphical fidelity certainly does. RAGE looks gorgeous, check out some of the screenshots I or others have taken and see for yourself the colorful environments that are pleasantly in line with the setting of the game. Ruined cruise ships sitting on top of cities made from industrial steel sheets, a town converted from an old subway station, a maniacal TV host with a carnival themed arena of death, RAGE continues to amaze with each chapter of the game fitting a well crafted post apocalyptic theme.Also of note is the attempt by ID to try new things with the standard shooter genre. Weapons have alternate ammunition types which alter the way they're used, some to a greater degree than others. There's also a light crafting system in the game that lets you construct items from health bandages to stationary turrets and even robotic spider turrets. While the game doesn't ever require you to need these items as even on the hardest difficulty the game can be completed without any of them, it's a nice addition that does allow for some different approaches to combat if desired.---RAGE does have it's negative sides however and it's unfortunate that this is all some people see in the game. It's been heavily criticized for it's ending sequence and yes, it does leave something to be desired. The last half of the game in general does seem rushed and not as creative as the first half although again the aesthetic and attention to detail is still there. Even right to the end the game each sequence is fantastic to behold with the level, enemy and weapon design being the saving grace for me.With the mechanics ID added to mix up the genre they came close to creating something magical but ended up stumbling a bit in the implementation. The driving mechanics first of all could have been done better. While it's fun to turbo boost yourself around the wasteland firing machine guns and rockets at other cars in a Twisted Metal fashion, the vehicle controls and enemy AI do feel lackluster compared the rest of the game mechanics. An afterthought kind of feeling can't help but be conveyed especially after your tenth or so race with the enemy cars driving ever so cautiously behind you as not to be too hard on you but not too easy on you either and then immediately dumping their ammo supply upon pickup in a very predictable way.While appreciated, the crafting and ammo system is also somewhat lackluster in it's implementation because while everything in the game is indeed fun to use on it's own, the game is not balanced well enough nor ever requires you to use any of what's given to complete the game. In fact if you play on normal difficulty you can very easily use nothing but the shotgun and the occasional showing of a rifle for the entire game. The disconnect between the ideas in the game and the implementation in conjunction with the enemy AI shows although. Again however, the fun in using the available mechanics is there should you choose to enjoy the game in it's fullest.One more thing to note and is as much of an afterthought as the mode itself is the multiplayer element. While nice to have, multiplayer does indeed feel tacked on offering two modes that are entirely forgettable. First there is a co-op mission mode but the missions are just rehashed levels from the campaign. You and your partner compete for points by killing enemies the fastest and most efficient. The other mode is up to four player races and destruction derbys that are more fun than the co-op mode but the race mechanics are dry enough that it doesn't redeem it as something that will last you more than a few plays.---Overall I certainly enjoyed my time with RAGE, enough to buy the DLC and complete the achievements. It's going up as one of my favorite shooters despite it's flaws and it's a game I wholeheartedly recommend everyone try.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 11, 2014
												5/10On the surface, RAGE is a great game. Great graphics, the gameplay is smooth, the vehicle integration is great, and the item based system is actually seamless. HOWEVER, I do not recommend this game as it has literally no story line. All those side quests you play in Skyrim, or pretty much any RPG now, that's exactly what this whole entire game is, a side quest. The character has no backstory, no progression, you aren't told what's going on until three quarters through the game (you can accurately assume the story, but no concrete statements are given). Even after you are told what's going on, it's not even a solid plot! There is no end game bad guy, there is no final boss, there isn't anything!I played on Hard right away, as I usually do with games, and it was WAY too easy. I never fully died, only went into the 'downed' state three or four times. You make money way too easily when you get a half decent card deck, and there isn't really anything to buy. There are a ton of guns which is great, but at a certain point the alternate ammunition is so powerful, that you can just use the shotgun for every enemy and one shot them on Hard difficulty. I realize there is nightmare and 'ultra' nightmare, but one shotting end game guys on Hard shouldn't be an option. Also, if you just use wing sticks through the entire game, you'll never die, and decapitate multiple guys in one shot. Hide behind a corner, pop out, throw the stick, hide, wait a second, and pop out to catch it.Those game mechanics break this game. The wing stick makes the few middle game bosses extremely easy as well, just shoot them all in the head a handful of times and death. What I'm saying is, this game is a level of easy that shouldn't be allowed in mature games.Lastly, they push you to go out and explore in the loading screens constantly, but there isn't anything to explore. The handful of areas that you can explore, are all tied to missions. This is a game that tries to make it seem like you can explore but really just forces you down a set path, it's almost useless to get out and explore because you'll end up going back to the same place, only this time no extra loot. AND the job boards that add the equivalent of side quests, they just send you right back to the same places that the main mission sends you. I'd say there are probably 15 explorable areas in this game, and each one you go to multiple times. Save your money folks.

content:
Posted: April 5, 2013
												Let me tell you a story. Bought game. Installed game. Couldn't play game. Updated graphics drivers. Updating graphics drivers disabled my graphics drivers control panel ( huh?). Tried to play game. Game plays! BUT... it locks up every 5 seconds for 1 second. So basically unplayable. Tried to figure out how to fix. Adjusted settings up, adjusted them down. Googled. Found solution. Must change setting in graphics driver control panel. Can't do that. ♥♥♥♥ U JOHN CARMACK!Amendment: Okay, so in January of the year of our lord 2013, AMD updates their drivers again, and I install the update for Bioshock: Infinite. Check real quick, and yes i can use graphics driver control panel. Reinstall RAGE(!!) and loandbehold it works perfectly. This game is♥♥♥♥♥ I mean, its just bland and unexciting, with the only really interesting bits being the visual detailwork. EXCEPT, texture warps are ♥♥♥♥ing everywhere. If you turn your head even slightly every single texture in the game loads right in front of your eyes. Yes, megatextures sounds like the worlds best ♥♥♥♥ing idea, but if you can't implement it properly.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 4, 2013
												Rage has a lot of problems…. Now I love ID games but rage is worse than brink and brink was quite bad itself I will leave that for a different review… What is wrong with rage’s story:Rage has a very short story that could be told in a few sentences to a few paragraph in video format it could  be told in 30 seconds and nothing would be lost. Nothing at all…. Once you get to what you think would be the end of the introduction to the story you are already 2/3rds the way through the game. Once the story starts to pick up the game just ends in one of the worst ways I have seen in a game. Nothing is explains, the big confendation with the “Bad guys” which has no face or character behind them or explaining why they are “bad guys” other than they make a mutant army and they want you to help them  to crush a small resistances group makes little to no since at all.The Sewers DLC:You are greeted with a man claiming there are sewers you can access throughout all of the game you just have to look for them. Guess what I only found the one sewer and I looked.The Authority Pack DLC:You get a set of armor that combines what all the other armors pick, making it pointless to pick from them. A car that is not worth using at all. You also get a double barrel saw off shotgun which is over powered. The gameplay:It’s a choir typical random door closes can’t move on till everything in rooms are dead. Wash rise repeat for most of the game. A few boss like mutants none at the end of the game other than mutants with guns which are still easy to kill and not a threat at all. Just save your ammo and punch them.  Has a racing part and driving parts which are meh. The over all game:The game suffers from a identity crisis it trys too hard to be a fallout, wasteland, borderlands clone with no depth to it's story or gameplay then randomly tries to be a racing game. Then near the end of the game tries to be like a game it should have been to begin with. Then it just cuts short right when I actually started to enjoy it. It’s a waste of money a waste of space, and a waste of ID’s time clearly Bethesda rushed ID to finish it because the engine, story, and gameplay is so bad. There is nothing to redeem itself.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 14, 2014
												This game is a disgrace to the gaming community.Pros: The game has a fitting name.Cons:1. There's no autosaving, meaning that if you don't save for a long time and you die, you get sent back to the point in time that you saved the last time.So, I saved in the beginning of a dungeon. I then completed the dungeon in about 30 minutes, and then got out and hopped on a vehicle and started driving, and when I got out, I clipped through the ground. http://steamcommunity.com/id/FallingFist/screenshot/3281173896709564961There was no way to get back up, other than reloading that 30 minutes old save, which I obviously don't want to re-do.I know what you're thinking, but:2. There's no fast traveling. There's so much driving back and forth, and it's really boring after some time, and if there were fast traveling, I wouldn't be stuck in this situation, falling through the ground.3. Invisible walls. They're everywhere. I'm not even joking. Every place possible. The entire world is linear and horribly boring and pale, and you can't even jump over a 2 foot fence because of the invisible walls.4. The textures. Everything in the world that you're not looking at is unloaded until you start looking at it. This means that if you turn around quickly, the textures will have to load properly, which sometimes takes up to 2 seconds. This could easily have been fixed with motion blur or something. I guess this is good if you have a bad computer, but in that case you should probably consider getting a better one. It's 2014. 5. The modding community never took off. I realize that this isn't ID's and Bethesda's fault, but the companies never even released a proper dev kit. WHY EVEN HAVE SUPPORT FOR MODS WHEN YOU WON'T GIVE THE DEVS SOMETHING TO WORK WITH!? All in all, I strongly recommend you to not buy this game. It's most definitely not worth 20 euros. In fact, don't even buy it on sale. If you want a futuristic RPG, play Borderlands 2. It's a great game, compared to this pile of poop."To describe this game's assness, all I can say is it's very as s." - The Angry Videogame Nerd, 4th of July 2007

content:
Posted: February 10, 2014
												Creatively bankrupt. There was hardly a shred of this game that didn't feel lazily borrowed from some other, better game, it should have had twice as much content, and most of the side missions involved running through the same instanced 'dungeons' you'd already been through once. The overall feel is one of lazy story scripting, lazy mission design, and cut corners.I appreciate that id is trying to 'modernize' a bit and give their shooters some RPG flavor, but that's not something you can half♥♥♥♥♥or it makes the game feel stilted and confined. This game-world still felt small and empty. There should have been so much more content. Story-wise this could have been very cool, too, but none of the other characters had any discernible personality to make them interesting, id blew their load early on with the 60-ft gargantuan mutant, and the last level / climax was a joke.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												RAGE.The plus points about this game are overlooked by all the negatives. I bought this game hoping it was an open world, exploration game, sort of like Fallout or Borderlands. I was very mistaken because this game is very much story driven and although initially, you get to explore a bit, but afterwards, it feels very linear. The fact that you can't even open your map(wtf, you can't explore without seeing a map) says a lot about "exploring" the world in the description of the game. The combat is also very..shaky, so to say because, well firstly, you can't reload while running and secondly you hesitate for a second to shoot after aiming. There's a small pause in shooting even though you've aimed. Its very irritating if you're not used to it. Other than that, you don't get a lot of side quests unless you absolutely exhaust dialogue with anyone you can talk to. This might infuriate someone, might not. Combat with cars is very aggressive as you can actually die if you're not careful even if your car is at full health. The plus points would be the graphics & textures and the realism of the game. but that is about it.I also hate the fact that so many doors in so many buildings are just "closed". It completely ruins the feeling of exploring the world. It just puts you on a very linear path of "do this and go here" instead of "don't do this, just explore stuff and come back and do this." You can't do that. I almost feel like this game can be compared to Singularity or Crysis because of the linear quest line and your inability to explore the world. The AI racing bots can be easily beaten in races. They're not even a threat after the first lap if you race well. Also, this game is really huge; around 18GB. All in all, I was highly disappointed from this game because I was expecting SO much more and it failed to give me what I had in mind. That being said, this was my opinion and I know people like this game a lot but I did not like it all.

In the event you are at all interested in a post-apocalyptic world in which people strive to patch together society against the onslaught of mutants and bandits, all while under the watch of a high-tech militaristic group, go play Fallout.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 14, 2015
												Another game I bought on release, stopped playing then picked it up later to finish. Where to begin?- Release for this game had a BUNCH of problems. Most notable was the Megatexture system they tried. While they fixed most of it. Some of the problems still linger, such as texture pop in, blurry and mushed textures. Like any other games associated with Bethesda. The game looks great indoors and at close ranges, looking into the distance is nothing but blobs and blotches.- The Gunplay is alright. There is some downs, some ups. But most of all, it stays average throughout the entire game. There is a good assortment of weapons and equipment you can use. But you'll just find yourself sticking to the same few weapons throughout the game, as using anything else is rather pointless.Lets start off with the Wingsticks. Holy♥♥♥♥♥♥these things are OP. There is no reason to use any other sort of equipment besides these. HE Grenades take to detonate, and won't always kill everyone. Turrets take forever to kill someone and can be destroyed with a few shots. Wingsticks however, once thrown will fly towards the enemy and one shot them, occasionally they'll fly back or you can pull them out of their skull. Which makes it easy to keep a surplus of them, later on in the game you can upgrade them so they'll fly around walls or cover, kill multiple people and then come back. You could compete the game no problem only using wingsticks.Some of the equipment is useless, or very situational. You do a quest in the first zone to get some RC car bombs. During this quest, you can use them to great affect and to complete objectives. They have small tunnels where you can drive these RC bombs through, kill people in cover and all sorts of stuff. However, no where else in the game features these tunnels and all the NPC enemies will focus fire these car bombs down. So there is no reason to use them again.Same thing can be said with all the ammo and weapon types in the game. Once you get a certain type, there is no reason to using anything else. Most of the pistol ammo is useless once you get Fatboys/FatMammas. The Crossbow is completely useless, as there is no stealth in the game so the Sniper Rifle works better for long ranged, all of the bolts are situational and much like the RC cars, useless outside of missions. Including the Mind Control bolts, which are supposed to be a "superweapon", but its just quicker and easier to dispatch people with another gun.The Weapon Upgrades, Inventory, Crafting system and everything else feel forgotten about. There is little reason to craft anything, the inventory has no limits. The weapon upgrades can be checked, but they're so few and used for four weapons. In the all, they all feel useless and you'll likely very rarely use any of them.- Racing and driving is seriously the best feature of this game. It handles better than anything else and feels great. - The Story is a mixed bag, I really enjoy the first area to the game. Its much bigger and most of the content takes place here. The theme is nice, people trying to make it by. Bandit and mutant troubles all over the place with people occasionally mentioning "The Authority" like they're some big bad. However, as soon as the resistance comes into play, everything else is practically forgotten about and you're thrust in with them with little explanation. By the time you're done listening to people mentioning that they're TOTALLY NOT IN THE RESISTACNE. You go do a quest in the Dead City. Which has a lot of hype built up around it, but in the end, it has little to do with the game. (Not to mention, it has a great atmosphere). You go in there, fight an extremely busy boss and then you're back out again. Then you're thrust into the resistance with no real reason to join them, other than "The Authority is bad mmkay." You finally get to run into the Authority and they seem to be a real threat compared to bandits and mutants you've been fighting. But midway through the mission they become a trival experience, as you get everything you need to fight them. Including pulse shots that oneshot them. EMP Grenades, which disable armor and shields, and armor piercing rounds. Which leave little reason to use anything else when fighting them. Besides Wingsticks. After doing all this, you have to do a few more missions, the town you're in starts becoming occupied by Authority. Which provides a good feel and some seriousness to the story. Then you're offered to head to the second area with the Resistance to help take the fight to the Authority and help end them for once and for all. The second area is completely devoid of any good feelings, atmosphere, etc. Its gray and bland. The most interesting thing in the entire area is a broken apart cargo ship. Which is only there for some neat factor. The rest of the story is suddenly thrust into your face and you're dropped in the middle of it. Then its promptly pushed to the side and you need to go do some errands for the towns Mob Boss Mayor and reputation so people don't rat you out to the Authority. However, the latter doesn't really affect anything. If you talk anyone in the town, they'll tell you that they already know who you are and that they're counting on you.You run around, do about 2-3 errands for the Mob Boss so you can get his approval to work out of his city. Which once again, doesn't make any sense due to the entire having been there for ages, and him being anti-authority. (Not to mention, everyone says you need to do this before you can do any sidequest/shopping. But as soon as you talk to him you can do it all anyways without completing any of his quest). So you do them, and then suddenly it doesn't matter anyways, because the Mob Boss was taken away by the Authority. Which gives a feeling of "Why did I even bother?" Then you need to go back down and talk to the resistance to carry on.You also have the option to do a few side quest, there is about 1-2 given by NPCs, and a few on the job board you can find. But is insanely lacking compared to the first zone. The second task given to you by the resistance, is to finally take the fight to the authority. You need to go disable some shields on the bridge and finally get to encounter some new Authority units, like their vehicles. However, you can one shot any of the authority vehicles with the pulse cannon on your own. So its another moot point.Once you're at the bridge, you take the lift up kill a few guys (literally about 6-10 guys). Disable the shields and head back to talk to the resistance again. Which then they inform you that you're now at the end of the game and this is the final mission and you're gonna take down the authority. You get in your vehicle, head across the bridge and find a conveniently place side entrance. The final mission is a cake walk, they give you a OP gatling gun so you can blow apart what few enemies you come across. You go through a few hallways, take a elevator ride up. You're now at your objective.It gets even worse, the final "fight" of the game is nothing more than a wave attack of about 6 fodder infantry, on three waves. So yeah, a total of 18 weak units. There is no boss fight with the General Cross, who everyone mentions throughout the game. You quickly dispatch these last few units, hit the console. Boom, game done. Cutscenes, credits. Overall, it feels like they ran out of production time. The second zone/part of the story is about 1/4th the content of the first area. The story is hamfisted and shoved in your face, which overall leaves a unsatisfying taste in your mouth. Which is a shame.I could describe a lot of other things, but I'm hitting the character limit. Overall, the game is mediocre and is only worth to buy when on sale for cheap. Its something good to waste a few hours on. But the racing and driving is great. I'd recommend buying it for a few dollars just for that.

There is no boss fight with the General Cross, who everyone mentions throughout the game. You quickly dispatch these last few units, hit the console. Boom, game done. Cutscenes, credits. Overall, it feels like they ran out of production time. The second zone/part of the story is about 1/4th the content of the first area. The story is hamfisted and shoved in your face, which overall leaves a unsatisfying taste in your mouth. Which is a shame.I could describe a lot of other things, but I'm hitting the character limit. Overall, the game is mediocre and is only worth to buy when on sale for cheap. Its something good to waste a few hours on. But the racing and driving is great. I'd recommend buying it for a few dollars just for that.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 22, 2013
												I made the big mistake to believe in the many reviews of others before I started to play Rage on my own. Thats why I finished the game like 2 years after release and the most bugs are fixed now I guess.  Anyway, as one of the last survivors of the human race you leave your vault to discover whats left after the apocalypse. You realise quick that there are a lot of others survivors out there which are spending their time in the wasteland. And thats how it begins, you shoot your way through sweet looking caves, mountains, bandit-hideouts and other places where monsters like to hide from the sun. To your assistance you have a big shipload of weapons to murder everything thats dumb enough to pass your way. As example, wingsticks, RC cars with c4, automatic turrets, railguns and way way more stuff. The open world is not really open world...You have in the beginning that feeling that you can do what you want and that there are a lot of places to explore. But in the end every place on the map has a purpose and is part of a quest.  COOP Whats worth getting mentioned is the coop campaign which is a complete seperate storyline and is very challenging either. Grab a mate and murder some guys! All in all I LOVED this game. Due to the many critics, I already had a bad feeling when I started playing... But instead I got blasted away by the charm of the game. ID Games did everything right in this game. PS: IF YOU CONSIDER BUYING THE DLC!!! Do it before you actually start the maincampaign. This dlc adds some new quests and locations and makes the game more complete. But you can do those quests as the campaign progresses, so buy it before you start playing the campaign.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful7 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 12, 2016
												One night I sat in my boxers in front of a gas heater whilst contemplating life and as I gently cupped my wrinkly nuts I thought, "Let me write a review for a game". The game is good, but not 41 hours+ good, yes I am ashamed of myself. Now, for the love of sweet baby jesus, why the Fnck oh wise one, why do thee rate it positive then? Well, I'll explain brutus. It looks nice, sound design is also good because the gun makes pewpewpew and that is fun, I guess. I swear to you I'm not fncking drunk. It's like wanting a zombie apocalypse to happen, thinking "Fnck, surviving will be so exciting", and then realising that you're basically just cowering inside a bunker until you starve to death. That's what this game is like but instead of hiding in a bunker like a coward you run and pewpew mutants...that's all, but the game does look really nice.Now there is racing, but just like the mutant pewpewpew'ing, you wroom wroom wroom with the 'WAS & D' keys. You have a super boost wrOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOm when you press space which makes wrooming past other cars easier. My down syndrome kid can basically win these races with ease if his grandpa would stop bullying him but that's a story for another review.Ok, Mutant PewPewPew: CheckCar WroomWroomWroom: CheckOh...there's a built in card game, it's like Gwent (The Witcher 3) and Hearthstone (Blizzard) had a baby that recieved little to no oxygen at birth, so the parents (Gwent and Hearthstone) were forced to do a C-section, kind of thing. I'm saying the game is like a mentally r3tard3d version of its parents before becoming an opiate addict at the age of 24. It's dark, I know but that's truly the only analogy I could think of at the moment. No, I'm not high.It's fun but in a sort of, "I hope one day when I'm 90 I might enjoy it" kind of way or more like, I like apocalypse vibes with a gentle wind in the speakers whilst staring at pixels being loaded into the environment kind of fun. I'm starting to wonder if this game is actually fun, ah fnck it.Buy this game when it's on sale but never install or play it. Let the mystery of never having played such a dull yet beautiful looking game be the emphasis of your enjoyment. Now go out there and get a sixpack whilst listening to motivational speeches or something!

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 17, 2015
												There are several reasons I stopped playing this game part of the way through the first level:1. Texture pop-ups. In case you haven't heard, they are incredibly egregious. They haven't fixed them since launch, and mods were only able to partially alleviate the problem for me- and I have a pretty powerful system.2. Gameplay was cookie-cutter whack-a-mole shooter. Enemy pops up, you shoot them. Sometimes they charge you, sometimes they stay in one place. Not very interesting.3. My gun was not fun to shoot, nor were my enemies fun to kill. The revolver feels like a peashooter, and my thoroughly unarmored, half-clothed enemies only seemed to emphasize the weapon's lack of power by dying only after being soaked in bullets. Some may say I should have stuck with the game, but I really couldn't find any redeeming quality in the early moments. With all the other options out there, it needs to do better to hold my attention. Thank Gaben for Steam refunds.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 24, 2016
												I bought this game thinking it would be good. It certainly didn't look bad on screens and reviews weren't that bad either.What a mistake this was.There's some kind of story that isn't that easy to follow as you are too busy being a good dog and fetching stuff for incompetent people who can't drive 500 meters to do it themselves.The graphics is okay, but definitely not good. While models look quite pretty and detailed, textures of the environment are blurry and very low-res. There's an option to turn details for textures on, but if you do, FPS goes WAY down and the change isn't even that remarkable.The sounds are standard. There's not much to say about them. There's also music that fits the atmosphere, but sadly isn't very memorable.When it comes to gameplay, the game takes some time to get used to. Enemies run around doing parkour stunts, so it's sometimes quite difficult to hit them (in the head). You can also drive vehicles and install weapons on them to be able to defend yourself from bandits who also own vehicles. Driving feels okay as long as you don't race. It's not like the racing is so bad, but AI drivers are masters of rally and you might have a hard time winning the first place. Races in the second part of the game are extremely frustrating.What kills this game are the minigames. They are mostly based on luck and even if they aren't, the game is ready to♥♥♥♥♥♥in your mouth anyway. It doesn't help that the game has achievements, which means more frustration for achievement hunters like myself as you MUST win all those unfair minigames. Did the lousy developers really think this was fun?To sum it up, this game is pretty much average. It's fine for people who don't go for 100% and avoid all the frustrating stuff the game has to offer. I personally was in rage several times, so at least the bloody title is fitting.EDIT: Finally did it. What were you thinking, idiots? Why so frustrating?

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 23, 2015
												Another in a long line of solid but shallow releases from id software.  This game has not been as revolutionary as id promoted, but the engine is legit, providing good visual quality, optimized and stable performance, and polished-smooth fps action.  Even the driving is fine.  But overall, like many id titles (post-Quake) the gameplay is shallow, streamlined, and simple.  The settlements in this game are filled with static npcs that might as well be statues, 95% of which you can't interact with.  They just spout a line of flavour dialogue as you walk past.  I beat the game last year but couldn't tell you anything particular about the plot.  Still, if you like post-apocalyptic shooters, this game may scratch that itch.  It doesn't have any of the inventory management minigames like the Borderlands series.  Rage probably won't hold your attention much beyond the initial playthrough, but if you like games of this type, it's probably worth $5 bucks.

												If you've got an AMD card then be warned this game might take a bit of tweaking to work. Other than that this is a great corridor shooter with splashes of rpg and open world elements. Weak on story but strong on gameplay.I have a love/hate relationship with the graphics involved in compressed megatextures (I love the landscapes and NPC models but hate the textures on most everything up close)Fun multiplayer but could have used a TMD or CTF element but instead  they focused on the driving and a smattering of co-op stuff, but the game does have an amazing vehicular combat multiplayer component.All in all a great game but wait for a Steam sale as it's not worth the price at launch.

content:
Posted: May 1, 2016
												The shooting itself is fun and all (all ID games typically tend to deliver in this regard), but driving from location to location is a chore.  It's a game which at first feels open world, but really it's just a bunch of short linear quests which you get to by driving to each of them.  Again the driving controls suck in this game which is why I already gave up on Rage due to sheer frustration (or should I say rage lol).  And then as part of the story, they require you to "race" to move along in the story.  Screw that.C'mon ID.  No one is asking for linear corridor games with driving requirements.  If I wanted a driving game, I'd but a driving game.  You should do what you do best and just put together awesomely fun FPS games.  Or make driving optional and put a "fast travel" option to quickly get from place to place.  Or make driving fun like it is in Borderlands.

												Good game, i enjoyed it. It was alot of fun to play. But wait! There's More! Nope! Just Kidding! This game is so short on content that i completed it in 11 hours. Yep, granted i was playing on easy so it was not difficult, but what, the battles i played would have lasted an extra 15 minutes a peice, so thats 13 to 15 "real" hours of content in the game. Its extremely small. Its like a dumbed down version of Fallout, as in Wasteland with freeroam and quests and such. But its way too short. After you save the group of people thats going to win the game, "Take the fight to the enemy!" the game ends. Like thats it. Congrats, you started the revolution that will destroy the bad guys, but you dont get to take part in it. There are only two (2?!?!?!) real "cities" in the game. Two or three small towns and just 2 city like places which add up to the content of goodsprings and novac in the fallout series. So yeah, its fun, if you can get it for cheap get it. But dont expect to play it over and over again.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 5, 2014
												RAGE is a post-apocalyptic open world shooter with racing and minor RPG elements. It sounds like it has some great potential, but it fails in multiple key aspects to the point where I only find it worthy of a neutral score.The gameplay blends all of these genres and ideas together surprisingly well, but that does not mean it executes them well. There is a decently sized arsenal with several attachments, but the gunplay itself is mediocre at best with few differences between each weapon. Both assault rifles function very similarly. I should also mention that the attachments barely seem present with only half of the weapons having a single one.All weapons have special ammunition types but they are very poorly balanced. The pistol's "fatboy" rounds can down most heavy enemies in about 8 shots and can be used effectively for the entire game. On the other hand, mind control bolts for the crossbow are weak, expensive and near completely useless.There is very little variety in enemies. Most enemies just mindlessly charge your position with no care in the world and the few that don't just hide behind cover until you take them down. Even the boss type enemies tend to follow these patterns.The racing is unable to save the poor aspects of the gunplay. Steering is astoundingly bad, there are few different tracks for racing and rally is just not fun at all.Crafting has some interesting components and items that can give you the tactical advtange. However, it is extremely underwhelming with few items to craft and little emphasis on it. I played through most of this game crafting almost nothing but bandages. The atmosphere isn't post-apocalypticy enough. The enviroment makes me feel like I'm in the middle of a desert or a canyon. The atmosphere is especially weak in the eastern wasteland. The soundtrack is also pretty bad.I want to point out that the end-game is extremely dissapointing and easy with the end itself being very weak. The mutant bash levels are more difficult than the ending and that's saying a lot.I would give this game a 5/10. With about 10 hour long playthroughs (probably 15-20 hours if you are a completionist), decent replayabillity and sometimes fun gameplay. But all of the flaws balance out with these good things creating a very neutral game.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												Definately not worth its price!I will tell you why.Rage is an FPS game set in an post apocalyptic and vast land. You are some guy striving through the lands, while surprisingly a mutant attacks you, another guy comes in and saves you. After that you will probably think "Oh this is quite big open world", well ♥♥♥♥ that. You have atleast some open world, which you will only see from your vehicle, because everything else is absolutely nonsense (You'll probably die, atleast in Ultra Nightmare, but i can't tell about the other difficulties). Once you accept a quest (you have to in order progress in the campaign) your destination is set and you move yourself in front of a dungeon-like entrance (no, seriously there is an entrance for every quest). Later in the game some scripted events in certain places will delay your arrival at your destination, if you are not cautious From that point on even Call of Duty is more open world than this game (also applies to each single level). The game also tells you to play a level again, in reverse. That happened to me once or twice i don't really remember, nevertheless it is definately too often in my opinion.To be honest, the animations are really good. Although they repeat themselves (no-few variety) as you can imagine. The graphics load themselves as you move on, none of them are preloaded so prepare yourself to see some washy/blurry textures if you really want to buy it.I spent about 7 hours and i was about half-way through, then i apparently "RAGE quitted", because i could hold on to see the lack of variety in this game.I hope my review on this game will keep your hands from RAGE.

content:
Posted: June 11, 2014
												*Please note that I havent tried any of the DLC and have no intention of doing so after my experience with this game.This review is a bit late... I forgot about this game and it was brought up in a recent discussion. I was asked if I thought this game was worthwhile.There is a clear answer for that, absolutely no.I loved how this game felt, how combat handled and alot about this game just clicked. However, I took my time with the game and still completed it in such a short time that its just silly...and the story was awful. I don't remember the story actually. I do remember my utter and complete shock when I stumbled upon the ending tho. I was literally taken by surprise and had no idea it was right around the corner. My girlfriend still remembers me swearing up a storm over what a waste of money this game was when that ending came out of no where.It's very seldom that I would say a single thing can ruin a game,..Cons: Game lengthPros: Almost everything else. It has great graghics, near perfect performance, combat feels right, and I enjoyed playing and interacting with the world. This probally only contributed to the great slap in the face when it all ended.*For anyone looking at my time played on this game... keep in mind there were 3 savefiles ran thru the game*

It's confusing, there's no clear path, everything is just over-wasted and over-textured, the bad guys are all nuts, the good guys are too nice and calm, and there's nothing to do for the first couple hours of just running errands before you can do races and get lost in some cities. number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 30, 2012
Single Player Campaign Review ONLY.RAGE is flat-out an awesome shooter, even despite its numerous problems on the PC version. There are numerous problems here: it's not the best technically running game; texture quality is all over the place; recycled areas (often on side quests); no real end-game boss; and a very abrupt & horrible ending. The game has lots of charm and atmosphere; it's somehow one of Id's better stories (if that's saying much); the voice-acting is excellent; and the combat and some weapons - i.e. RB bomb cars & mind Control Darts - are awesome.Even after all of its issues, RAGE is still a pretty good shooter. It's just that RAGE could've been greater than what it is, if only Id would fix the numerous issues & actually finish the story. With the game still shining even amidst all these problems, that's saying A LOT and speaks volumes about this game.SP Campaign -- Grade: B-If I touch the Multiplayer, I will re-review this game & include that in there...

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												Definately not worth its price!I will tell you why.Rage is an FPS game set in an post apocalyptic and vast land. You are some guy striving through the lands, while surprisingly a mutant attacks you, another guy comes in and saves you. After that you will probably think "Oh this is quite big open world", well ♥♥♥♥ that. You have atleast some open world, which you will only see from your vehicle, because everything else is absolutely nonsense (You'll probably die, atleast in Ultra Nightmare, but i can't tell about the other difficulties). Once you accept a quest (you have to in order progress in the campaign) your destination is set and you move yourself in front of a dungeon-like entrance (no, seriously there is an entrance for every quest). Later in the game some scripted events in certain places will delay your arrival at your destination, if you are not cautious From that point on even Call of Duty is more open world than this game (also applies to each single level). The game also tells you to play a level again, in reverse. That happened to me once or twice i don't really remember, nevertheless it is definately too often in my opinion.To be honest, the animations are really good. Although they repeat themselves (no-few variety) as you can imagine. The graphics load themselves as you move on, none of them are preloaded so prepare yourself to see some washy/blurry textures if you really want to buy it.I spent about 7 hours and i was about half-way through, then i apparently "RAGE quitted", because i could hold on to see the lack of variety in this game.I hope my review on this game will keep your hands from RAGE.
